I didn't pay for it, figured it was the least they could give me.Last, but certainly not least, they have NO RESTAURANT ON THE WEEKENDS. Who closes their restaurant on weekends? I was looking forward to a night in with some delicious four star food. Room service? Nope. They brought up some menus. One of the places was closed already and it was only 8pm. ??!! We eventually ordered from grubhub. I wanted room service because I wanted china and real utensils and a decent meal.I will never go to this place again. Ever. They spend a lot of money on aesthetics and failed to spend the pocket change it would have cost to have a top sheet, a coffee maker, and some damn food. They nickel and dime you on the continental breakfast, though. Not cool. Not cool at all.
user_name:
BDavis20744
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: A great hotel in the financial district - the king room was large for Manhattan snd well appointed. The bed was like a big cloud - sooo comfortable and a very clean hotel.

Stayed at the Gild Hall last month and I was pleasantly surprised. I just moved from living in New York for 7 years so I am well aware that the financial district shuts down on the weekend but as a former New Yorker enjoyed the quiet streets and neat little finds for pubs and places to dine. It is also walking distance to Tribeca where you can find a little more night life. As for sleeping it was quiet and enjoyable. The staff was overly helpful in recommending places close by and gave us a room upgrade upon checking in (even having booked at a very discounted rate). If you are looking for the bright lights and touristy NYC don't stay here but if you want to enjoy a bit of New York off the beaten path then I highly recommend the Gild. Not to mention when the Monday rolled around the hotel was a buzz and you can't beat happy hour on Stone Street.
user_name:
NewYork_hotelsnob
New York City, New York

review_body: Very nice hotel, I love the look here - English Hunting Lodge meets up-to-date mod cons (a la heated floors) in a nicely lived in design that wasn't aggressively trying to be hip. AND, AND I was upgraded to a suite! sweet!!!!! :-) (I think the key here is to check in later i.e. 8pm to have this happen to you.)The location is out of the way (if you wanna walk to Soho, LES or the Village for example) but the subway is a close 10 min walk.p.s. A TIP for y'all - I get the best rates for this hotel on http://www.quikbook.com shhhhh. the hotel website sometimes does match it.One thing to keep in mind: on Saturday nights they host insanely packed and loud parties in the lobby and 2nd floor library, so make sure to stay on floor 8 or higher to avoid the noise - I heard nada from my 18th floor penthouse ;-)

I loved this hotel. Quiet and private. Nice staff. Stayed here five nights. Only thing: no bellhop on the weekends. Night manager couldn't help me get an cab early this morning. They could only call town cars. She was helpful by pointing out that I could catch one on the street. That was the only bad moment which wasn't even so bad. Downtown, so pretty dead on the weekends. You can always catch a cab, though, down the street. Ha!
I previously stayed here before for a business trip last year and it was a no brainer to return. Like before service was great! Looking forward to my next stay.
I previously stayed here before for a business trip last year and it was a no brainer to return. Like before service was great! Looking forward to my next stay.

I found this hotel to be just what I was looking for. It was quite, the employess were fun and it looked like they liked what they did and had fun with it. I never saw one employee not smiling which is refreshing. I stayed over the weekend and it was perfect! I will definitely go back. I live in the tri-state area but like to get out of my everyday routine. Gild Hall is a place worth staying at. Thank you for a great weekend hope to see you guys soon.

I recently stayed here for the second time during a weekend in the city and would recommend it to everyone. The location is great and just a short walk to the subway. The decor of the hotel is unique and very quiet. The rooms are a very good size and extremely clean. Also of importance to me, the beds and pillows are super comfortable, which is often rare. The staff are friendly and very accommodating. Nothing but good things to say about this location!

Recently stayed here for a business trip. While I enjoyed the quietness of Gild Hall vs other financial district hotesl that are near the WTC construction site, I was disappointed in little things missing that would have made my stay more enjoyable, amenities I have grown used to having even in economy hotels. First off, there are no down pillows, I spent the entire night trying to get comfortable on a styrofoam filled pillow. Secondly, there are no inroom coffee makers. Additionally, there are no inroom irons/ironing boards, almost a necessity when trying to press a suit that has traveled in your small carryon luggage.

I've stayed in the Gild Hall several times, and have to say I was deeply disappointed this time. The hotel is effectively shut at the weekend, so all they are selling you is a bedroom (at not inconsiderable cost). As always at the Gild Hall, the room was nice - comfortably and fashionably furnished is a sort of 'leather and dark wood generic American boutique hotel' sort of way; not imaginative - just that sort of US Luxe look that you see on makeover shows. It's cute that they provide an in-house magazine worth reading - but frankly I'd rather they actually OPENED the hotel properly at the weekend. They don't provide breakfast (unless you count a mount of cheap muffins and other sugar-based substances as 'breakfast'. It's 'continental only' at the weekend - served casually on a table in an un-lit corner of the bar / reception area). Frankly, it's depressing. You're made to feel like you are staying over in a boarding school after everyone else has left. To get a hot breakfast i had to go find a local diner - OK for what it was, but after spending to be in a luxurious hotel, don't expect to breakfast in a diner with the hobos. There's no room service either (the front desk provided takeaway menus, which was kind of them, but again not really a solution). The worst element is that (presumably in order to save electricity / the planet) they only light a tiny part of the reception area - leaving the (shut) ground floor / first floor bars and the restaurant in darkness - which adds to the feeling that you're not welcome. In it's favour, it's close to Fulton Street subway, and Century 21, the location has atmosphere and it's not that expensive. But Thompson Hotels big themselves up as the coolest thing since sliced bread. This place lacks the fundamental hospitality I expect of a hotel, anywhere in the world at any time of the week. It's NOT MY FAULT it's the weekend. If they don't want to run a hotel at the weekend they should just shut down Friday thru Sunday. Never again.

I have stayed at this property a few times now for both business and pleasure. It is located in the downtown/financial district but easily accesible to the subway. The staff is very friendly, the rooms are extremely clean, decor is chic, the ceilings are high and the rooms are quite large for NYC. The TV is large and the bed is incredibly comfortable. I used to live in the city and have stayed at many properties in the area and have to say that the hotel offers very large accomodating rooms. Their pricing is great on the weekends. I always have a wonderful experience at this property and certainly recommend it friends, family and coworkers.

We got a great price on an air/hotel package from hotels.com that included our three night stay at Gild Hall. The room was clean and comfortable. We used the fitness centers separately since there is only one elliptical in each fitness room, but everything worked fine. The property was close to a subway station. Gild Hall is nice, but I didn't find it special enough to rate 4 stars. I wouldn't have paid more than the $99/night for the place.
user_name:
ReneeSutton70
Canandaigua, New York, United States

review_body: There were 4 of us staying for 4 nights from Sat 11th Feb - Weds 16th Feb, upon arrival our first impression was that it was tastefully decorated and welcoming, we were offered a glass of sparkling wine complimentary upon arrival, which I thought was a nice touch.Although we had pre-paid for rooms and continental breakfast for the duration of our stay, we had to leave a deposit of $50 per room per night, which was not the usual card swipe, be warned, I had taken a pre-paid Mastercard with me with our spending money on it and was not told the money is actually authorised from the card and reserved against any charges, which meant I was $200 down immediately (Incidentally even though we have been back home for 5 days - those funds have still not been released on my card, I was told by the hotel they would be back on the card the evening of the day we checked out!)The Rooms were nicely decorated, the view was looking directly into the apartments opposite [we were room 143 on the 14th floor], our friends room was opposite ours and their view was of a construction site, which was noisy during the week [forget a late sleep in!]The bed was comfortable and room very clean, the ipod dock alarm clock was a great idea, as was the safe for valuables.Unfortunately the restaurant was shut on the weekends - the lobby bar was open, prices were good $5 for a Stella Artois [£3.25 same as UK], Bottle of Corona was a bit expensive $7 [about £4.50] - it is also customary to tip $1 per drink on top.It was perfectly safe to walk around at night, you can always flag down a taxi, they were cheaper than back home, we took a trip to Little Italy, it cost $8.If you stay in and around the hotel on the weekends, be prepared for it to be quiet, we went to Jim Brady's Irish Bar/Restaurant around the corner at 8:30 Saturday night and there were only 2 other people there! [food was nice and not expensive, the barman even put the football on the TV for us]. For some nice bars try Stone Street, about a 5 minute walk!Most beers are $5-$8 (included imported and 'fancy' beers - such as white beers], wine is more $9-$11 a glass, and that's the cheap stuff.Breakfast at the hotel wasn't great, we had pre-paid for their continental breakfast at $15 per person per day, but for that all you had was 1 piece of toast and jam and a small serving of fresh fruit, your $15 (£10) did not included tea/coffee/juice [approx $5 each] or service charge at 18% - so even though we had pre-paid for our breakfast(which was a meager portion for $60 per day for 4 of us - approx £40) we were then presented with a bill for almost $16 (just over £10) for bringing us 4 slices of toast and fruit![On Sunday - there was nobody working the kitchen and we helped ourselves from a selection in the bar area, there was no service charge and we took as much as we wanted - much better idea!]After Monday morning, we found an excellent deli around the corner 'Lane's Deli' where the owner (Gabe) and his staff offered an excellent breakfast, a huge selection and great prices - we had our fill of toast, bacon, eggs, juice and tea for around $7-$8 each [£5], for the rest of our stay we cut our losses with the continental breakfast at the hotel and ate there! [they also had a huge choice for lunches and dinners and the food was great and cheap!][they will even do you a packed lunch to take out for the day].Taxis : We arrived at JFK and straight away someone tried to scam us with a fixed taxi fare of $68 to take us to our hotel in lower Manhattan! Make sure you ONLY get a taxi off the rank - the flat rate to any hotel/location is $45 + tolls [approx $6] - we paid $51 for our journey which took about 45 mins. When we returned to the airport on Wednesday we paid just $45 flat rate as the tolls are only one-way [we left in evening rush hour and it took 1hr 20 mins - allow plenty of time]. You don't have to agree a price, it's all on the meter. Also, whilst at the hotel the doorman got us a taxi one evening, when we arrived at our destination the driver added $4 onto the cost of our $8 journey, because the doorman had taken a ride from the main road back to our hotel and not paid the driver [annoying!] - moral: get your own taxi, there's loads around.Trains : we purchased a metrocard which gives unlimited train, underground and bus travel for 7 days for $29 [£20], the underground [subway] was easy to use. Make sure you get a streetmap at the hotel, it is really simple to use and you can find your nearest subway station from various attractions.Attractions: Arrive early - and avoid the queues, a New York CityPass is a money saving idea, we purchased ours online before we travelled and they cost £52 each - we used ours to see Empire State Building, Statue of Liberty/Ellis Island Ferry Trip, Museum of Natural History, Metropolitan Museum, Museum of Modern Art and we ran out of time but could have gone to the observation deck of the Rockerfeller Building.People: are amazingly friendly and helpful - every time we pulled out our map someone would stop and ask if we needed help or where we were looking to go.Would I go back to NY? - yes definitelyWould I stay at this hotel again? - probably not, I'd go somewhere more uptown!
user_name:
Rochelle L
Hemel Hempstead, England, United Kingdom

review_body: The gild hall is a cheap price for manhattan, but so is every hotel in the financial district. I was fully aware of the location and know manhattan hotels very well. The room is very nice no complaints there. The bed is comfy, the tv is big, bathroom is excellent, the decor is unique in a good way. But, these details alone would never make a hotel a 4 star in any city. There was no bell on saturday night to get a cab and a cab would likely never drive by the hotel so this is unacceptable to ever leave the hotel without proper staff unless of course you were not trying to be 4 star. There is no bar or restaurant in the hotel on weekends. No room service. No coffee maker or coffee anywhere in the hotel. No iron to iron your clothes. No conceirge to help you choose somewhere to eat which is obviously necessary downtown because its not the type of neighborhood you can just wander around and hope you find something. Most of the financial district shuts down on weekends so the hotel has to at least try to be educated on this. I knew all of this about financial district before hand but did not expect a 4 star hotel to be this clueless and literally have 0 service. The front desk is nice but they do not qualify to be a conceirge by handing a list of restaurants with no descriptons. The doors closing are extremely loud and obnoxious to the point where you will not be able to sleep past 10 am. House keeping does not care if you put do not disturb sign up they will most certaintly come knock every 20 minutes starting at 9am.I am being very detailed in my complaints because of this hotel being advertised as 4 star here and priceline. I am fully aware you get what you pay for, but i just dont like the false claims. This was for our anniversary and i wanted a 4star hotel.

the lobby is cool and thats it! No room service or restaurant at weekend..you feel in the middle of nowhere and the rooms have one little window looking on to peoples apartments who look into your room..its dark..and the carpet is black making it even darker...Really disappointed and will never go back... the rates are low..and once you visit you realize why !!!

My boyfriend and I both live in NYC and wanted to do a little "staycation" in the city. We found this hotel on a whim and booked it. We were SO pleasantly surprised. Leather tufted chairs, well-styled bookshelves, and beautiful objets adorned the very handsome lobby. A parquet staircase led to a gorgeous bar with a great ambiance. The room was immaculate and new - very comfortable bed and huge shower complete with Bigelow toiletries. We slept in, checked out an hour late and were not charged extra, the staff was super accommodating and friendly. All in all, a great value (probably the best value in NYC) for a stylish and modern hotel with great customer service.
user_name:
Nicole N
New York City, New York

review_body: I was very excited to stay at Gild Hall while in town for a job interview. The staff were friendly (especially the incredibly helpful doorman who walked several blocks to find me a cab) and I thought the room was huge for NYC, with very high ceilings that contributed to the spacious feeling. The bathroom was also very clean and modern, and loved the CO Bigelow toiletries. I especially appreciated the welcome plate of fruit and cookies from Thompson Hotels after a long train ride and late arrival. However, the downsides: I could easily hear the music from the bar from my room on the 6th floor; there were only two small elevators and I (and another hotel guest) waited more than 5 minutes for an elevator in the morning; and I don't know why, but I found 3 spiders and a mosquito in my room! (And one spider was on the shower curtain!) I killed all of them and so didn't have any reason to tell the front desk about them, but you might want to check your room in case. Maybe the combination of an unseasonably cold night and an old building brought them out?

Gild Hall is located in a fantastic area downtown. Very close to several subway stops, the Path Station, and a number of great bars and restaurants. The staff were very welcoming and helpful with information. The decor in the hotel is exactly as pictured. Our room was beautiful and clean. Very spacious bed and a perfect night sleep awaits. The room had very high ceilings and was very spacious for their standard room. Large bathroom and shower as well. We had some drinks at the bar before heading to Les Halles, one of their reccomended restaurants. The Happy Hour was fun and they have a nice selection of bar bites, and alcohol. I would certainly stay again.

This hotel is for those who need to be close to a downtown office or meeting, but want to be in a block that is quiet, convenient, and near several subway lines. Gild Hall fits that description well. Room is very nice; bathroom nicely done, although with translucent glass door/walls, if you are traveling with someone, the slight lack in privacy might be an issue. Otherwise, very clean, very comfortable. Nice little business center on the 4th floor; I used one of 4 computers in there, and so no 'wi-fi' issue for me, as reported by others using their laptops. Buffet breakfast is a little pricey, but a short distance away is a Starbucks (open at 7am), and a place called Earl's Court, which has Soupman brand soups, Billy's brand cupcakes, and a lot of other nice food/goodies.Staff is excellent (particular Evan, one of the bell men - very helpful). I did not try the restaurant or bar, but looked nice.

This hotel has a good location, near Wall Street Metro Station, lovely rooms and good amenities in the room. The Bar is quite busy during week days with the office people from around the hotel. During the weekend (i stayed 4 nights) the area is very quiet, so if you like to chill out and not have the NYC buzz around you 24/7 this is a good hotel to go to. Internet is only charged buy the day i had to print my boarding pass for my flight back to the UK and phoned reception to ask what the other options where, they suggested to come down and they would do it for me. Great service. (suggestion, why not give 30 mins free internet per day, this will solve the problem!).Accross the road is a nice cafe place, they do have free internet (no you cannot pick it up from the room i tried it :)So overall, good hotel, near some of the sights (Wall street, Brooklyn Bridge, WTC site etc). But very business orientated.

Stayed here on 23rd January. I was at a conference in downtown Manhattan. Normally I stay in larger hotels in midtown but Gild Hall was conveniently located. Very pleasant decor and a welcome change to the big, busy midtown hotels. However, wifi was appalling and I understand from another guest who was also at the conference that the business centre was poor. The fitness centre consisted of a treadmill and a cross trainer plus some weights in a small windowless room. almost an afterthought. For a hotel just by Wall Street they need to get their act better regarding services for business travellers.

This is the perfect getaway in NYC: a quiet but yet convenient location in the Financial District, a couple of great eateries nearby, and the hotel itself was absolutely amazing. The decor blew me away and I loved that the lobby had a little library of books which you could help yourself to. The room and bathroom was spacious, clean and very beautifully decorated. It was a nice romantic getaway for my boyfriend and I! I'll definitely be staying here again!

If you're looking for a cool, modern hotel on a budget, Gild Hall is the place for you. Exactly as pictured on the Thompson website, the rooms are masculine, clean and chic. The lobby and common areas are original and inviting. The staff makes you feel like they actually care when they ask you if you like your room. Located near Wall Street and South Street Seaport, there are plenty of bars and restaurants within walking distance of the hotel. Lastly, our bed was comfortable and we didn't hear a sound all night! We would stay at Gild Hall again without hesitation.
A great find. Worth taking the 15 mins on the subway to get anywhere you want to go. Love the friendly staff. So NOT NYC!!!

Reasonable price and central location to many NYC attractions. The hotel is located not only close to Wall street and World Trade Center, but also close to Statue of Liberty and Staten Island Ferry Dock. Moreover, with express subway, Time Square, Central Park, and Rockefeller Center are easy to access from the hotel. We paid $99+tax / night, and the employees at the hotel were very friendly. Moreover, the hotel was very clean and a good service.
user_location: Washington, District of Columbia, United States
user_name:
Hyunsu C
Washington, District of Columbia, United States

review_body: The first week of December two of us stayed 4 days at Gild Hall. The location was close to the Financial District and Seaport Village along with easy access to subways. The location was quiet, clean and large rooms. The breakfast of coffee, juice and danish was good but should have been free instead of $7.50 per person.

We paid $129 + tax on a deluxe king through TravelZoo during Christmas. We requested a higher floor room so we could have better sunlight. Really liked the room. It felt clean.I feel it was well designed to utilize space smartly. The room has open built-in shelves and customized narrower furniture to make it feel spacious. Bed was firm and comfortable. Good size bathroom, simple, modern, and elegant. The bathroom door was somewhat translucent. Since we are a family with a young kid, we had no problems.Service was adequate. Requested late check out and higher floor room, got what we wanted. It was a short trip and we didn't need any extra service.Though there was no coffee machine in room and the bottle water was not cheap, there was a nice supermarket only a block away. Very easy access to get simple food and drink.We would definitely consider staying here again.

Terrible customer service, fire alarms that went off all night and shabby interior that is in desperate need of a freshen up. Looks great on the website but I wouldn’t send my worst enemy to this hotel!

We just enjoyed two nights at the Gild Hall hotel near Wall Street. As far as hotel rooms in NYC go, the price was excellent, the room comfortable and clean. The translucent bathroom doors were a bit unsettling. The only other comment we had was that there was no coffee maker in the room nor was there room service for morning coffee. They did however serve coffee in the main lobby as well as pastries. I am not sure if there was a cost for this service or not. The area is full of coffee shops so it really wasn't a problem. In room coffee would have been a convenience for sure but it would not prevent us from staying there again.

If you plan to stay at Gild Hall in Manhattan's financial district, either request a top sheet or bring your own. Otherwise, under the hotel's "European-style" bedding, nothing will separate your comforter from the bottom sheet and mattress.In December 2011, I stayed two weekday nights at Gild Hall. This represented my second visit. Shortly before I initially visited Gild Hall more than a year ago, Thompson Hotels had taken over and renovated the property. Hotel occupancy rates were depressed, and management seemed willing to please. Upon my second visit, the bloom somewhat had faded.Gild Hall offers a convenient location for those wanting or needing to stay in the heart of Manhattan's financial district. The hotel's also convenient to various subway stops, rendering other parts of metropolitan New York easily accessible. My room's HVAC worked reasonably well, providing either heating or cooling depending on needs.Paying $364 per night despite having reserved many months in advance, I was disappointed that the bedding included no top sheet. Having only a comforter to cover me disrupted my sleep. Upon checking out of the hotel I mentioned that I would've appreciated having a top sheet. The front desk responded that Gild Hall features "European-style" bedding but would've provided a top sheet had I requested one. In this traveler's opinion, Gild Hall should prioritize providing travelers restful sleep over honoring any particular bedding "style." For the room rate I was paying, it seems reasonable to expect the bed to include both top and bottom sheeting. I noted some additional shortcomings. Most of the times I showered in my room, I had difficulty obtaining sufficiently warm water. It was also disappointing that the clock radio in my room provided no access to a.m. radio stations. Some terrific, iconic a.m. stations broadcast in the New York area; I missed not hearing them during my visit.I appreciated that Gild Hall provides on three different floors (6, 7, and 18) areas for exercising. However, all three workout areas proved small and limited, apparently shoehorned into former closets. Each area provided only two machines: a treadmill and a stair stepper. In the area closest to my room (floor 18), I while running on the treadmill could not activate the accompanying television's sound system. Travelers seeking more intense indoor workouts should arrange in advance to visit one of the financial district's extensively appointed (although not inexpensive) health clubs. When again needing to stay in Manhattan's financial district, I would consider returning to Gild Hall. However, I would relish reexperiencing the enthusiasm and willingness to please I found on my first but not my second stay at this hotel.
Great Location walking distance to South Street Seaaport and the Seastreak Ferry to Atlantic Highlands NJ. Great rooms, clean,comfortable and great service and attention to detail.

I have just returned from a week in NYC. I stayed at the Gild Hall Hotel in Lower Manhattan and was really pleased that I did. The hotel is ideally situated for the Financial District and only a short walk form Ground Zero, Broadway and the subway system. There is a choice of restaurants, bars and food shops nearby, so eating well is not a problem. The room was spacious and spotlessly clean, the towels and linen were of superior quality and the mini bar was well stocked with good products.The hotel is designed to look and feel like a gentleman's club and the library on the second floor was a great place to sit and relax. The bar looked welcoming and the restaurant, although I never sampled it's fare, looked to be of high qualityI found the staff to be friendly, professional, very helpful and welcoming at all times.Would I go back a second time? Absolutely, and without doubt.

My husband and i stayed here over the veterans day weekend.We chose it based on other reviews AND the price. We LIKED the fact that it was quiet. In the past we stayed uptown, close to NYU and it can be VERY noisy. The room was clean, the bed was very comfortable and i liked the " funky" non traditional decor.The staff was very helpful, friendly and accommodating. We drove and had no problems finding a parking garage a very short distance from the hotel. There are several subway stations nearby and Broadway is just up the street when we chose the cab option. We would most definitely stay here again.

My husband and I spent last Saturday night at Gild Hall. It met all our expectations. That is, it is a small, clean, well-priced hotel close to Ground Zero and the Financial District. I read earlier reviews posted here, and the fact that the bathroom door is semi-opaque and there's no restaurant weren't relevant to us. (There are plenty of eateries in the area, including Les Halles, where we had a delectable brunch.) Back to Gild Hall: We were delighted that a room was available when we arrived, even though it was 11:30 am. Every member of the hotel's staff was friendly, professional, and helpful. One caveat: If you drive to NYC, do not valet park your car. It's vastly overpriced. (I was told it was about $55 per 24-hour period, and if we went over the 24 hours, it would be another $55.) Instead, go to the parking garage up the street, which was much cheaper for a stay of more than 24 hours. Oh, and check out your room's minibar. In addition to prosaic offerings, like soda and candy, there are condoms and what appeared to be discreetly wrapped sex toys.

My sister and I just stayed at Gild Hall and I'm very happy with our decision. I found the front lobby really nice, the room was clean (and spacious for NYC standards), the furnishings were modern, staff was really friendly/helpful and it was nice and quiet in the evening in the rooms (although the downstairs bar looked pretty busy). A couple of friends said they didn't think it was a good idea to get a hotel in the financial district over the weekend since not much would be happening... I actually thought the opposite. It takes a quick subway/taxi ride to get wherever you want to be, and you get the benefit of some peace and quiet when you return home late at night.Would definitely recommend this placeOnly criticism: I would say it's more of a criticism on Kayak's part, it said that a. there was a 24 hour cancellation policy (when in fact, if you purchased one of the special rates, you were charged up front and not allowed a refund) and b. breakfast would be included. While breakfast is included for some guest packages, it wasn't included for us which was what Kayak stated. Again...I think it's a Kayak issue, but something to consider when booking. Oh, and also the decor in hallways (where the rooms are) are pretty cheesy, but nothing huge.

We were looking for a reasonable place to stay for the weekend and this hotel had a nice special. We got upgraded to the suite because it was noisy when we arrived and they left us in it for the next night as well. Very nice digs. Clean, elegant and the staff was very helpful. Close to the subway,but hard to get a cab so you have to be willing to walk to find one.

I stayed here in July with my 17 yr old daughter. We both liked the decor. The bar is conveniently in the lobby, however, the bartender was also the restaurant waitress and so was very overworked and stressed. She gave me excellent drinks when I commiserated with her!We used this as a launch pad for SoHo and it was good for that. It's about a 2 block walk to the subway and changing was easy. We also found a discount dep't store right at the entrance to the subway and took full advantage of that!Room- stay there only if you really know your room partner- the bathroom "doors" are some sort of see-through rice paper material.Bed was comfortable. You need to request a top sheet if you want one.All in all, I would stay there again, but not with a male.

I booked through the Tablet Hotels site for our wedding anniversary weekend at a great last-minute weekend rate. Thought it would be fun and different to stay in the financial district. The decor was a bit unusual. The lobby was done up like a hunting lodge with leather sofas and antler chandeliers and the room was decorated in dark, masculine colors. I would have liked an armchair to relax in. There was a window seat, but it wasn't quite deep enough to sit comfortably for any length of time. Arrived on Friday night and the bar was pretty crowded with what looked like an after work crowd. It was so loud I couldn't hear the desk clerk as he was checking me in. when we came in from dinner on Saturday night the bar was just as loud, but completely empty. Fortunately, the room on the 10th floor was nice and quiet with a view of the narrow street in front. Comfortable bed, nice toiletries, chocolates on the pillow at night. Nice bathroom, but it had a glass wall, so it's a good thing we have no secrets from each other. Location was convenient to lower Manhattan and close enough to several subway lines. All in all a good find for a weekend stay.

This hotel was dismally average. The restaurant is closed all weekend, which is terribly inconvenient, and room service isn't available on weekends either. In fact, even weekend breakfast is a rather dismal affair (you'd be better off at Starbucks). Basically, pretend this place doesn't have a restaurant and your expectations will be more in line with the service provided. The parking is an utter debacle, we wound up being billed twice for parking, and having to park ourselves despite the alleged presence of a "valet." While the front desk staff was very nice and helpful when they were around, it also didn't appear to be a real 24 hour front desk. For example, when we showed up at 6am, the man in the parking garage told us that (a) the front desk had to call to get our car, and (b) the front desk staff was unavailable and (c) he knew they would be unavailable, because they were never available this early. He suggested we visit their break room. This is just silly. A final point - the heat did not work properly in our room. It was a frigid 68 degrees, even after someone came to "fix" the heat. When we told the staff on checkout that we found this unacceptable, no discount was offered -- not even after it was revealed they'd double-billed us for parking. That's the reason I'm never coming back.However, if you don't mind being cold, hungry and overcharged, the location isn't bad.For a much better downtown hotel, check out the Andaz.
user_name:
Paloma A
New York City, New York

review_body: My fiancee and I recently attended a Friday wedding on Long Island and decided to relax in the city for the weekend. After looking around, we were able to secure a relatively affordable (by Manhattan standards) night at Gild Hall through JetSetter. We were very impressed by the design of the hotel and the comfort of our room. Usually we stay in Midtown, but this turned out to be a great place to stay. We were able to walk across the Brooklyn Bridge for breakfast and with a number of subway lines in the vicinity, you can easily get uptown to where you want to go. I would definitely think about staying here the next time I'm in Manhattan.

Stayed at the Gild Hall this past weekend and had a great time. The room was a good size for New York City as well as spacious and clean. There was a charge for internet which is annoying but I wasn't on business this trip so it wasn't a big deal for me. What really made my stay so great was the staff. They were very friendly and helpful, especially the young man and young woman at the desk who greeted me with a smile and friendly good morning each day. There was some subway construction going on at the near by station so some of the subway trains weren't stopping and the staff were very informative about alternate routes and what trains were going where and where not. I would have been lost with out them!

Terrific hotel in the heart of the financial district. Staff was very accommodating and helpful on a first stay in this part of NYC. Great location for getting to know lower Manhattan and convenient subway access to other parts of the City. Comfortable room -- liked the firm bed. Only drawback - very loud rap parties to walk through in the lobby on Friday and Saturday nights . . . but not audible on the 16th floor.

My wife and I like to travel one weekend a month within in the United States from California. Out of all the places, we find ourselves going back to New york City; been there so often that we like everything NY. If it wasn't for my law firm, I would definitely live there. Needless to say, we have been to many hotels located in Manhattan. However, Gild Hall was the by far the best! I have been to $600+ a night hotels and not always impressed. Nevertheless, not only is the price reasonable a Gild, but the tranquility of the rooms (even the lobby) is surreal. It was a very stress free stay. I wanna give my gratitude to the well trained staff. They were excellent. where ever a person stays, hospitality is KEY. I can stay a palace and if hospitality is horrible, so is my stay. I appreciate how manager Ben, involves himself with the hotel on little details and not only when there is a major issue, if any. I've had clients where their situations could have been resolved if managers had involved themselves to either prevent or neutralize the complications. It takes more than just standing around to be a manager. Gild Hall proved it; very impressed. Once again, clean rooms, well decorated, good price, love the atmosphere, love the staff, and LOVE THE LOCATION!

I have stayed at this hotel on several occasions and find it has everything I need to feel comfortable and at home. There is not a huge gym but on a few floors there is a room with a running machine, elliptical machine, bike and weights which is all I need. The in room dining is excellent and is my preference as I have found the restaurant staff to be slow.Some nights there are events in the bar/ library area which appears very loud but not heard when in the rooms. The front desk staff can appear at times a little aloof but the bell boys make up for this with the service they give. The beds are extremely comfortable and due to the quietness of the area you always get a good nights sleep!

We booked this place on August 30th, 2011. I called the front desk at that time and asked for some information about the amenities. I was told that on Saturday and Sunday they had a complimentary continental breakfast, I believed them. On Sunday morning on October 16th my wife and I went down for breakfast. My wife had a piece of bread, cup of coffee and a little bit of fruit and I had 1/2 cup of coffee and a piece of rye toast. The coffee was a disgrace, it tasted like tar, it was so thick like it was last weeks coffee. We got up and began to leave, when a waiter walked over to our table with a bill for $38.06 I was astounded. It was an outrageous amount for a "complimentary" breakfast. Needless to say, there was a sign on the side of the room out of view that said Continental Breakfast $15.00 per person. I went to the front desk and told the manager we refused to pay for this, he looked up our room number and told me it did not apply to us as complimentary. When I explained to him what I was told on the phone he said he would not charge us so I asked for a paid in full statement. I will not recommend this hotel to anyone friends, relatives or co-workers.

I stayed at the Gild Hall last month as we found a great deal online for the weekend for a city getaway (we're from Long Island). At first look, the hotel is spectacular, the decor is just like the pictures and even more beautiful in person. The rooms were comfortable and had a unique feel to them. We were very happy with the overall appearance of the hotel.However, there were more than a few things that really turned this trip into a disaster.During check-in, the woman's cellular phone rang. This was a little surprising and really threw off our expectations of this hotel. I'm not sure if it's normal to have your cellular phone with you at reception but this has never happened to me before anywhere else. I later asked one of the gentlemen bellhops (who were very helpful in fetching cabs and attending to bags) if this was normal and they said that she was the manager. What's next was even more surprising to me and my husband. For some reason 3 out of the 5 times we visited the desk, the girls were barefoot!! I'm not sure if it's because their feet hurt in the shoes or what but this was extremely unpleasant to the eyes, I'm definitely sure this isn't normal uniform policy.Lastly, the Libertine restaurant. While they actually have good food. The service was terrible! The waitress would disappear into a room behind a closet and we would have to wait for her to come out to order something or get a check. It took exceptionally long for us to receive our food, about 45 minutes for a hamburger. Later in the night the restaurant turned into a club and I was told I had to go around the side of the hotel to go back into the bar for a drink by a large bouncer in the middle of the lobby. I wish I could have enjoyed my stay more and left a better review. But there are some service failures here that I could not overlook. I pay high attention to detail and the little things really can ruin a great stay.
user_name:
Chelsea H
Great Neck, New York

review_body: The decor is interesting and gives the hotel a hip, yet cozy feel. Things were slightly beat up--not too bad but you can tell the hotel has been around for a few years. Amenities are limited. Surprised that only one bathrobe was provided--kind of sad, no? Very loud bar scene downstairs with a not particularly savory or hip crowd in attendance.Biggest bummer for me is that--all though hotel advertises that it offers both a restaurant and room service--it didn't. Front Desk gave us a list of restaurants in the area. However, I was really surprised, given that this is a Thompson Hotel, that the list wasn't better "curated' to include select new and interesting restaurants downtown. The list was like someone googled restaurants in the area and printed them out, including really bad South Street Seaport tourist restaurants. I would expect that at a Hilton but not here. Front Desk told us on Saturday night that there would be a limited continental breakfast in the morning but we woke up Sunday and were told by the Front Desk, "Oh, we're not doing food today." So major disappointment in every way possible regarding food.Staff were pleasant and personable but it's clear that they are operating under reduced circumstances--there must be alot of pressure on the hotel to keep costs down and sadly, it shows. Probably never again.
user_name:
FreqTravel77
New York City, New York

review_body: Take a great boutique hotel, add a super staff and a good rate, equals one great experience.

I have stayed here for three nights. Hotel is alfhearted about amenities: you'll find a bathrobe in your room, but no slippers. Good bed, which I find important, and that's about all I remember from it. The hotel does not offer anything 'special', it lacks character, I think.

We had a wonderful stay at Gild Hall this past Aug. 2011! My son lives accross the street, so it worked out perfect for us. The hotel was very clean, bed comfortable, and and the decor was real trendy. It does not have your typical drawer space for clothing, but what they did have was plenty for the two of us over a weekend. Why stay at a Holiday Inn when you can stay at a Thompson property for the same money!They even have a complimentary umbrella in the closet to use if there is rain during your stay! We kept checking their rates and found a very good rate that fit our budget...also a free "welcome" drink coupon was included! Yes, it may be quiet, which was great for us, but they have the South Seaport only a few block away which was great to just tool around! We loved it, and would stay again! Kathy Liberatore

The hotel is very quaint and a very high end boutique hotel. The rooms are designed fabulously. The service is fantastic. I rate it 5 stars and highly recommend the Thompson hotels as a fantastic value.

I spent a week at the Gild Hall in Mid-September whilst on business in New York.The Gild is a nice enough hotel, and boutique in style.On the plus side it is in a quiet location and very close to the the heart of the financial district.On the negative, given how close it is to Wall St. as a business base the rooms let it down.I needed to work in the evenings, and ended up sitting on the bed as the desk (if you can call it that) provided was totally useles; it's only about 18 inchs wide and already clutered with a lamp and drinks trap before I tried to squeeze a laptop in only to find the slot to slide my knees under the desk was in a corner, directly below the lamp. OK I could have shifted the lamp and other bits, but there was no where to shift them too. Frustrating.The iPod docking station in my room was broken too.Other than that a typical NY hotel room; on the small size and dark (something else I don't like).OK for a short break, but don't expect to do any work in comfort in an evening.If you do stay, there's a good dry cleaner 50 yards down Platt St. who do a next day service (dry cleaning & laudry) for a fraction of the cost of the hotel

Stylish and trying but doesn't live up to the Thomson Chain brand and is on the lower end of boutique hotels. No room service on the weekends.....carpetting in the rooms needs cleaning (this on the basis of two rooms)....the room bathrooms have a door facing the bed and the entire entrance (wall and door) of the bathroom is transparent - even if you are travelling with a very close companion, this becomes frankly weird. No fan in the bathroom (so a long shower fills the room with steam), ventilation uneven in the room (super cold or no air at all)....no coffee maker in the room, and your closet light is connected to the neighbors - so when you walk by the closet you and their light goes on. They walk by their closet, your light goes on! Digital signal on the television (not that you are in NYC to watch tv but....) is slow and uneven. Limited food in the area - remember it's the financial district - but it's close to the Seaport which is a really nice part of the city, fewer tourists and calmer, quieter etc. On the positive side it's quiet and the staff is super helpful.Like this hotel enough but the weird bathroom issue is enough to have me stay away. Boutique hotel? At between 325.00 a night they need to do better.

First of all, the entrance to this hotel is on Platt, not Gold - we definitely did frustrating laps of NYC after exhausting Gold Street as the flags on the hotel emphasize the Thomson Chain rather than Gild Hall itself. That being said, once we found the hotel our overall experience was great - the gentlemen at the front desk and dealing with the cars were all exceptionally polite and friendly. For example, When we asked for a map, they offered to recommend sites or routes to walk around. Our room itself was nice - very masculine finishes with a leather headboard with buckle details and a black/grey theme in bathroom. My two main gripes - the bathroom, while well appointed had a few minor frustrations. First, there is no bathroom fan. This can be less than ideal for showering as it results in an overly steamy bathroom but also, and this might seem funny, but there is a certain degree of privacy afforded by the bathroom fan. Especially when the bathroom and the 'living space' is less than 5 feet away from one another. The bathroom door itself also didn't close very well and had 'ribbed' glass so my fiance laughed that he could see me through it. Finally, the fancy design of the shelves didn't really allow toiletry bags to fit properly and the sink was a pedestal design which didn't help with storage either.Secondly, for a rather refined hotel, the connecting restaurant, Libertine, was a major disappointment. We received a voucher for 20% off and even so felt we grossly overpaid for substandard food. Several things we asked for were unavailable that evening, including french fries and a few appetizers. Because we were on a 'splurge trip' we got dessert despite a fairly disappointing meal and the sorbets were half melted, which our server pointed out by saying 'yeah they are kind of melted but you have spoons..." The restaurant also felt fairly run down - the sticky bar feeling that I associate with university days rather than a NYC hotel.Overall, would stay there again happily if I planned my meals better beforehand. It didn't help that we stayed in the financial district on a stat holiday so everything was closed in the evening.

Me and my girlfriend visited New York City last year for the Eminem and Jay-Z concert at the new Yankee Stadium in September of 2010. We looked up on the internet which hotel to stay in the city. My girlfriend picked Gild Hall because she thought it must be nice if it was located in "Financial District". I was skeptical but she was right! The great service started as soon as the cab pulled up at the front entrance of the hotel. Check in was fast and simple as if they new it was us as when the cab pulled up. The hotel manager, Benjamin Chan (if i remember correctly) knew what he was doing. He knew all the places to get the NEW YORK FOOD that locals rave about, even restaurants in Queens. Everyone was professional just the way i like it. NICELY DRESSED and courteous. Pretty much everyone was in a suit and tie and NOT sloppy. That's one of my pet peeves. You can't just have a nice suit (especially one that doesn't fit) but you also have to look good!. Nicely decorated rooms,very clean and everything was operable. Actually one of the elevator went out of service as my girlfriend and I were going to Megu(which recommend if you want the best quality of beef) but on our way back to the hotel, it was already fixed! I was in the Marines for four years and now I'm a successful designer and I worked hard my whole life; I want what I spend to be worth it and everything perfect. Gild hall did the job and I recommend it to anyone who knows and appreciates quality. Note: When we headed out to go to the concert(which was AWESOME!), my girlfriend wanted to experience the NYC subway system. Again, the manager came to the rescue! He gave us the best way to get to the stadium with added information on the area and how the subway works!

I stayed here for one night on September 11. This hotel is in a great spot situated in a quiet area. I had a great night sleep (which is almost unheard of in NYC). My room was well appointed but a typical small, cozy NYC hotel room. The bed was comfortable. The staff was very friendly and helpful. While I didn't go to the bar it appeared to be a very hip and happening spot. I would recommend this hotel and I would stay here again.

For New York City weekenders, this hotel is an outstanding deal. I'm almost hesitant to write this review for fear driving the rates up! We travel to the city for weekend trips fairly regularly and Gild Hall, while not conveniently located for those wishing to waltz out of the front doors into the bustle of Times Square, is fantastic. Spacious rooms, helpful staff, very clean rooms and amazingly quiet because the financial district is a relative ghost town on the weekends with narrow little streets that taxi drivers hate, let alone buses and trucks. The decor is decidedly masculine but understated and the accommodations are always very well cleaned. My only complaint is the lack of free WIFI. Our most recent trip to the city turned out to be a terrible ordeal involving a broken car, an almost missed meeting and a terrible meal to top it all off. Gild Hall was the highlight - a consistently solid refuge at the end of the day.

This is a new hotel located just a few blocks from the stock exchange. Less than 5 blocks from the train, this hotel is in a really cute neighborhood that is not super touristy. They had a DJ on Friday night and the bartender knows what she is doing. Our room was huge and very clean. I would for sure stay here again!
user_name:
Mpls223
New York City, New York

review_body: My parents wanted to come to New York for a visit and I didnt want them to stay with me. I found them a room at Gild Hall. When I came to meet them after they checked in, I was floored by the vibe in this place. It was incredible. We had dinner in the Libertine Restauant there. I highly recommend the burgers! I went up to the suite they had. I was ready to have them stay at my place and I would stay there. The kitchenette was nicer than my full size kitchen. My parents had only been there a few hours, but everyone was greeting them as if they were old friends. I am thinking of staying there over Thanksgiving weekend. My folks said there awas a lot to do. I hardly saw them. THANK YOU, GILD HALL!

I have been traveling to New York City for business pretty regularly these past few years and I have tried the budget places and the break the budget places. Finally, I have found a place that I want to return to. As soon as I stepped in, I fell in love with the layout and decor. The people were incredible. Hector checked me in and made me feel welcome, like I was arriving at a friends house. The room was great! It was the most comfortable bed I have ever had at a hotel. Most of the time, I stay in my room when I get in. I could not wait to get downstairs and relax at the bar. I cant say enough about this place. I wish there were one of these everywhere I travel.

The hotel was well situated in the financial district. Staff was incredibly friendly and even the cleaning staff would greet you. The lobby was small but well appointed. Rooms were good although the glass door on the bathroom did not lend for privacy on a family trip. Hotel has 3 small cardio areas and a good reading room that serves as a bar on weekends. Rates appear to be steep but you can find good weekend rates. Close to South Street Seaport and other financial district tourist attractions, as well as Chinatown.

The value of my stay for the dollar is almost unmatched in NYC! The rooms are exquisitely designed and the in-room ambiance is tranquil. The bar scene is vibrant and the staff are the best! I would definitely suggest.

Very cool hotel and great downtown location. Hotel had character - great art, nice lobby, attention to detail everywhere - and rooms were bigger than average.Staff were A+ everywhere. Front desk particularly, happy to give recommendations. Special thanks to BEN. I had left my car keys in the room safe after checking out; I called to explain my situation and Ben retrieved them and had them waiting at the front desk for me. This place goes the extra mile.

This is my second stay at Gild Hall - our office is a few blocks away which makes for a short walk into work in the morning. The hotel is definitely a boutique, which I like. I get bored with the "standard" hotel feel sometimes and look forward to the surprise of a boutique. The lobby is well appointed with an adjoining restaurant for breakfast, lunch and dinner. (We have had breakfast a few times in the restaurant - it's pretty slow - so if you're in a hurry you may want to opt for another venue.) In the evening, the restaurant turns into a hopping bar scene. I was really surprised because it's so sleepy during the day. Not bad, however, it added a nice vibe when walking into the lobby in the evening. The staff is always very helpful and the service has been great. The rooms are comfortable and well decorated. I love the "buckle" detail on the leather headboards. I was surprised at how spacious the rooms were - especially for NYC. The bathroom is tiny, however. It's a "one person" space. But . . . with very nice detail. I thought the glass door separating the main room from the bathroom was very posh. However, I read some reviews where others said they didn't like it. I had a king size room both times I've stayed. Both rooms were directly off the elevator and I think they're a bit larger. I was worried about it being loud due to the close proximity of the elevators - but trust me - I heard nothing. Not even the "all night noise" that is typical in NYC. Maybe it's because my room faces into another building - very close! Just keep your blinds closed and you'll be fine. There's plenty of drawer and closet space and a neat mini bar area. The only negative (besides the slow service in the kitchen) is that both times I stayed at the hotel my room keys (all 3) became demagnitized almost daily. I swear I didn't have them next to my cell phone. I had to go to the front desk often to have them rekeyed. If you want to workout I'd recommend Crunch Fitness. It's two blocks away. They charge $15/day if you show you hotel key. Also, for awesome, healthy food - try Energy Kitchen. Also just a few blocks away. Nothing is over 500 calories. They open at 7:30am for breakfast, too. The Gild Hall will be my "go to" hotel for business travel in NYC. Great price, great location, awesome vibe!

I found the best rate at this hotel. It was clean no bed bugs, not the greatest view, but I guess that is NYC for you. They have a nice happening bar on the weekends and a small grocery store and pizza place near by. The location is a little far south if you want to explore NYC but the price almost helps ease the cost of the cab fare. OVerall great stay though.
user_name:
Karen W
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Went here on a whim with a friend. Got a great price online for the Gild. Hotel was very nice and appeared just as it did online. Beautiful furnishings throughout and beds were super comfy. Service was below average. Reception greeting was a smileless hello. Later sat at the bar to have a glass of champagne, 3 people at front desk (hotel is small, bar is right next to reception area) saw us sitting at bar where there was no staff and no one acknowledged us. After 10 minutes bartender comes out and she was actually really nice and helpful, giving us suggestions for dinner and manicures. Next day at check out we spot what appeared to be a complimentary continental breakfast (self service set up with the usual pastries and yogurt) was set up in bar area, so we walk over and proceed to fill a bowl with yogurt...and again, no one was staffed there. Then out nowhere someone comes out and informs us that costs $15, so we put down our bowls, not yet touched and said sorry we don't want it. She says, 'oh ok, I guess I will throw it out.' Um, don't put food out w/ no signage if no one is working, otherwise this will happen, as I am sure it's not the first time. We only paid $150 for the night (I believe the usual price is double that), but for this Thompson hotel, I definitely expected better service.

The Gild exceeded all of our hopes, dreams and expectations. Every single employee made us feel we were of the utmost importance. The service was beyond compare, the rooms are squeeky clean, and the food is superb. Look no further. This is the hotel for you.

We went on a short trip to NY for a famiy wedding and the Gild agreed to a set price per night for everyone booking there for the wedding, which was a nice incentive. Their location in financial district is close to subways but not very convenient for weekend stays due to reduced service in the area. Do not plan on room service even though it is available unless you are patient and have time to wait. Only attempted to call once and after the call continually crossing back over to the front desk we gave up. The rooms are very nice with a well stocked and pricey snack tray and refrigerator. Grab items at nearby store & avoid their goodies. There was a $10 bottle of water - really? We were lucky to be on the top floor so the street, and traffic noise was minimal. The staff is helpful, just not overly friendly... more the stern but polite personalities.

We had a normal room booked here for 3 nights. Due to the hurricane my brother and his girlfreind joined us and we needed a bigger room. They were sold out but went above and beyond to provide us with a bigger room with not that much of an increase. With everything shut down during the hurricane, Pablo, the GM, played host and many of us came down to the hotel where we drank wine, beer, soda and he gave us free pizza. It fekt like staying at home but being in luxury. I am never staying anywhere else but here from now on. The rooms are amazing but the service out did it all. Bravo for whoever put this staff together because they really are great.
user_name:
mstern03
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: My Husband and i got a great deal for 3 nights and loved the downtown location . Rooms were spacious, clean and the hotel is a boutique for sure. Never to stay Midtown agaiin!

Love this hotel. It's a little bit away from some main attractions but we loved the decor, more space than an average hotel in NY. Since we traveled with our 16 months old, there was plenty of room for a crib. The decor is just so hip and modern, it was a pleasure. The staff was more than accommodating. And the price was great, we booked through their site directly. Oh and we got campaign when we arrived.
user_name:
Yulichka
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Thank you Gild Hall for an amazing 5 day stay in NYC, I could of not chosen i better hotel. As soon as i walked in front office reception where really nice and friendly had several question and they where able help me and get me the information I needed. The rooms where spacious, clean. I liked that they are located in downtown Manhattan and was able to walk from the hotel to South Street Seaport and transportation to other places was not hard to get to . I liked everything about this Hotel its clean, friendly and convenient to everything. I will definitely recommend this hotel, cause I will stay here again next time!!

I stayed here for my birthday last year and keep looking for a reason to stay again! I live in Queens and work in NYC so I decided I would treat myself after a recommendation of Gild Hall from a friend. After checking the website I called and booked a room for 3 days with my friends. The staff at the front desk was helpful and super friendly. Upon my arrival to our room, there was a note from the concierge manager, Hector, wishing me a Happy Birthday with a little treat for us!! I also work in the service industry and you don't find this level of detail everywhere, I must have mentioned it was my birthday on the phone when I was booking.....I had an opportunity to thank him in person when I was checking out. The hotel's interior design is beautiful and welcoming. The rooms were spacious for NYC and the beds were heaven!! I don't normally write reviews, but in this case, I felt they deserve recognition for they great experience they provided us!!
Stayed here for a week and enjoyed the usual style of a Thompson hotel. Amazing location for Wall Street financial district, ten mins from Soho. Great service. Nice breakfast

We loved it! Everything about it was just A+++. We stayed 2 nights this past weekend, dined in the fun pub area, enjoyed the amenities of our room (the translucent bathroom door is not an issue b/c it is not visible from the main area). The dinner was cozy and creative and the multiple wait staff was very attentive and timely. The doorman was quick to assist with the doors and handled the loading of the car in the rain beautifully. The "Adirondack meets the Wild West" theme is throughout and works just great. The linens were 400 count and the bed superb. NO disappointments: NO hesitation.

The Gild Hall is really nice. Luxurious, comfortable, quiet, and close to the public transportation. The employees are very friendly and do their best to accommodate you in anyway possible. My room looked really nice, its had very interesting decor, check out the website to see what I am talking about. Its like a modern retro kind of feel, I can't explain it, but I loved it. My room had an iPod dock, bath robes, and all the fancy stuff hotels provide. The only issue I had was my room phone didn't work so I had to use my cell phone to make calls. Other than that my room was spectacular.My stay over all could've been better. I went to the Libertine Restaurant which is a part of Gild Hall and I wish I didn't. I called them every 10 minutes for about an hour before I planned on arriving and no one ever picked up the phone. When I finally went down I was told there was a 25min wait. Which I could've avoided if they picked up the phone. So after the 25min wait turned into 40min, I was upset and went for a walk. walking past the restaurant window I noticed there were three open tables. At this point I wanted to leave but my fiance insisted we stay; so we stayed. The manager seemed nice, but the waitress made us feel like she had better things to do with her time. The food was great though. I'm a sucker for good food, so I kinda forgot about the horrible service when I started eating. So to sum it up: Gild Hall is great stay, but beware of the Libertine.

Stayed at Gild Hall from Thursday until Sunday with my wife and son. Had a blast at the bar/club Thursday and Saturday night. The DJ's,staff and bartenders were the best of NY. The hotel is in close proximity to some great sites and restaurants etc. It's nice to walk down to the pier and catch one of the sightseeing buses or ferry ride. The only drawback was no swimming pool and a better view but overall I was very pleased with the service and the room. I love hip hop, reggae, rnb,house, rock whatever and the DJ's in the bar kept me entertained. Bring the family for the daytime touristy type stuff and hang out in the bar after hours ;)

I have stayed at Gild Hall many, many times in the past 6 months. I felt I needed to share what a wonderful Hotel this is. The staff is wonderful, professional, informative and most important - polite!! The rooms are large by NYC standards, beds are extremely comfortable and my room has always been clean and NEVER had a bed bug problem...something you need to be very careful of in NYC. There is a very quaint bar which is always welcoming as well as the dining area. This hotel is located very close to the subway, and cabs are easy to get as well. I highly recommend this hotel for business or personal travel to the City. I have stayed here for 6+ months and will continue to book only this hotel no matter where I am visiting in the city!
Stayed here for a business trip and enjoyed the professional and personable service upon arrival and departure. Will definitely be back! The rooms were great too!

We really enjoyed our stay here. The staff was excellent and made us feel very welcome each time we came through the lobby. We found the location to be great. While the instinct of many visitors to New York may be to stay as close to midtown as possible, a stay at Gild Hall shows that this is not necessary. Being downtown, the hotel is close to every subway line, which can quicky take you anywhere in the city that you want to go. It is also close to Battery Park and the Statue of Liberty Ferry and is a generally safer neighborhood than most parts of midtown. We were able to spend as much time in midtown as we wanted, without paying the premium for a midtown hotel. We will definitely stay here again when we come back to New York.

We got a really good price via priceline. (120$US/night)Located in the Financial District, close to a Subway Station. Small rooms;Modern; Beds are really comfortable;Not really a nice view of NYC;No bed bugs;Clean;

We had great service at Gild Hall. The rooms were great - clean and fun. The location was great as well. It was a short walk to my meeting and was within walking distance to Tribeca and great restaurants.I will go back when I take a personal trip to NYC. I like to stay in the Financial district even on weekends. It is so close to everything but so far away - a bit of an oasis - peaceful and a quick walk or cab ride to everything.

My husband and I found this gem of a hotel through a Priceline bid; we traveled to NYC over Memorial Day weekend, and were looking for 4 nights in a hotel away from the bustle of Times Square, but still convenient. Gild Hall exceeded our expectations - the only thing lacking was the dining service/areas and lack of free internet, described below, which resulted in a 4-star review rather than 5-stars.Location: A little hard to find, but as long as you know that the main entrance isn't actually on Gold Street, you'll be fine. Most cabbies had no problem getting us back to the hotel after nights on the town once we said it was across the street from Harry's Italian restaurant (GREAT pizza and open late, by the way) and two blocks from the Seaport. The subway is just one block away from the hotel, a gourmet food/convenience store is located a few doors down, and there's a Starbucks less than a block away. For us, it was the perfect locale, in an area with numerous restaurants/shops, sans the crowds, near both the subway and a quick 5-minute walk to the Seaport.Design: The design of this hotel is perfect; the interior looks like a cross between a cushy boutique and the library of a mountain lodge. The staff is well-trained and attentive. We never saw the person providing daily maid service to our room the entire time we were there, but no matter what odd hour we departed/returned our room was made and there was fresh ice. The bedding was comfortable, the room was fair-sized for a hotel room in the city, and there was plenty of storage space. The bathroom had a shower only, but the fixtures were attractive, clean, and modern. The only thing I'd change about the room setup is that the entire wall between the bedroom and bathroom is frosted glass - in other words, if someone is using the restroom and you're in the bedroom, you can see (almost completely) and hear through the bathroom's opaque wall, offering VERY little privacy. The hotel boasts a second floor bar, but we never ventured there. When we returned from our nights out, we entered the lobby (which is partially open to the 2nd floor bar area staircase) and were greeted by deafening Top 40 music selections. The guests we saw staying at this hotel ranged in age from mid-40s to late 60s; in general, not the type of clientele who appreciate top 40 music and certainly not music blared so loud that conversation is difficult just one floor below. On the up side, we couldn't hear the music from our room on the 12th floor. On the down side, we did not - at all - entertain the idea of checking out the bar for an after-dinner drink.Food service: There is no room service, but the hotel has a small restaurant open for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. We ate breakfast in the hotel the first morning after we arrived. The restaurant had 2 customers when we came downstairs at 8:30 AM, but we waited almost 10 minutes to be seated. Our waitress brought out the wrong food twice; she did not write our order down and the cook ended up coming out himself to take our order. In all, it took almost an hour from the time we ordered to get two correct omelets delivered to our table, one with ham and cheese, one with mushroom and spinach. The food was delicious, but the waitress was definitely sub-par. We spoke to the registration desk and they immediately removed the breakfast charges from our bill; the very apologetic and very efficient customer service desk absolutely made up for the annoyance of breakfast, but we didn't eat another meal in the hotel during our visit.Additionally, if you plan to work at all when you arrive at the hotel, keep in mind that you'll have to pony up $9.99/day for internet service. We opted for our cell phones and free internet at Starbucks on the two occasions we needed access during our trip.Even with the minor annoyances, we will likely stay at Gild Hall again. I never would have imagined that you could walk out of a hotel in NYC at midnight and feel like you're in an abandoned city. The location is ultra-quiet, free of crowds, the decor is fabulous and the hotel is kept exceptionally clean, the customer service is outstanding (one waitress aside) and it's a wonderful jumping-off point for whatever you might be planning to do in any section of the city.

Stayed here with my girlfriend for a little weekend getaway. From the moment that I walked through the door, I felt welcome and was was happily impressed with everything. The staff was courteous and friendly. We stayed in a premium king room and was extremely happy with the clean room with very high ceilings. The bed was comfortable and the Air conditioned room felt amazing on the hot summer day. Can't wait to return.

After reading the reviews for this hotel, we were really looking forward to it. While some fine its quirkiness to be charming, we found it to be disappointing. First of all, we were not greeted with the promised glass of Preseco, nor were we informed about any amenities. We did not receive a daily newspaper as promised. We found the rooms to be small, and the lack of a dresser or a place to put folded clothing was annoying. There was no iron in the room or stand to hold a suitcase (which we had to keep out to hold our folded clothes!) The transparent sliding doors to the bathroom do not offer alot of privacy...and I would NOT recommend sharing a room with anyone you did not want to see what your bathroom habits are. We were surprised to find there was no coffee making in the room or available in the lobby. The only option was to purchase a carafe from room service for $8.00 with a $7.00 delivery fee. No soda machine in the building.Finally, the bed is made without a top sheet. You have only a duvet and a bottom sheet. I truly doubt the duvet is washed with each customer, so that really add to the "ugh" factor. I did get a top sheet on request - I was told the lack of top sheet is a "European" custom. THE LACK OF AMENITIES MAKE THIS NOT WORTH THE COST.

My friends got me a room at the Gild as part of my birthday/bachelor party. The room set the stage for what would be a truly great day. The rich dark wood that adorned the space felt smooth like a cigar. We’re a quick hop to stone street, one of the most happening streets in the financial district, home to Ulysses & an outdoor mini party. It was like a suburban block party on steroids. Thanks to Gild’s prime location, we were able to hit the hotel room before moving on the meatpacking district. The staff gave us great advice on places to go & spots to eat at. The hotel bar was so good we almost didn’t leave to hit the next spot. Sophistication practically drips off the bar.I’m looking forward to having another excuse to stay here. Definitely a great place to stay.

I stayed here with a friend a few weeks ago. We got this hotel off hotwire because they bunched it up with soho/financial district so to our disappoint we got this hotels. This is a Thompson hotel and the rooms were fine and the service was decent. My main complaint would be the location. If you are visiting nyc for business this may be perfect but if you want to be in with the action this is not quite walkable to soho area.

If don't know your way around NY downtown, you'll have problems finding the Gild Hall. Even the taxi driver with a GPS was puzzled. It's not as close to the subway as it could be, specially if you have luggage, but it's worth the struggle to get there.Very well trained but cold staff, small spotless rooms with modern gadgets. We had no view, not even the sky as the hotel is in the middle of taller bildings.Good TV, HD channels, good on demand selection.The mini-bar is complete. Dean and DeLuca snacks, condoms, disposal cameras and electric adapters are there for a small fortune. Fridge packed, no place for our stuff.In spite of all the problems mentioned, I'd stay at Gild Hall again, hoping they include courtesy in their next staff training.

I recently stayed at the thompson at gild hall in the financial district in nyc with some girl friends. we absolutely loved it. the staff was amazing and extremely attentive. they knew all the great spots to go to and had some excellent tips. any request we had they not only fulfilled but they ensured everything was to our liking. the room is beautiful and spacious. maria was the manager one night and she had an awesome attitude and was extremely nice. ben was another staff member who made us feel very welcome. this was the second time we stayed at gild hall and we will never go to any other hotel in nyc. i go to nyc about once every other month, usually for pleasure and gild hall thompson is such a great place to stay, mainly because of its awesome staff, great location and beautiful decor. the bar downstairs is also great and has some great happy hour specials.

I spent a few nights here prior to and during my wedding weekend, and the staff at Gild Hall could not have been more accomodating. They upgraded my room and greeted us with a congratulations note and bottle of bubbly. Our room was the perfect size with high ceilings and a huge comfy bed, perfect for pre-wedding resting. Our room was spotless and the bathroom was the perfect size. The location is on a cozy Financial District block, that makes you feel like you're in another city, away from the bustle of NY life, but not far from anything of necessity. The awesome decor is that of a neo-British hunting lodge and was the perfect backdrop to feel transported to another world. Thank you Gild Hall, your hospitality will not be forgotten and I will recommend this hotel to anyone I know travelling to NYC.
user_name:
andeedee2
New York City, New York

review_body: Gild Hall really impressed when my girlfriend and I stayed there last month. The service was great, room was spacious and bed was super comfortable. This hotel is located in the heart of the financial district, but succeeded in making us feel like we were at home. It was convenient for all of the trains b/c they all basically converge on Wall St and Fulton St.Far and above better than a standard chain like the Hilton or Hyatt and a great deal, too. Highly recommended - we'll be staying there next time we're in NYC.

New York is tight on space. At Gild Hall, a boutique hotel, allows me to forget that space is an issue.Booked a king bed on the 5th floor and would return on my next visit. Here's why:+ The room is pretty big. I had a king bed and it fit the bed without my having to skirt around it. Plenty of room to lay out luggage, get dressed, and just move around in general.+ Bathroom is pretty modern and clean. Great water pressure. Slip into the Frette robe and wash up.+ Flatscreen TV, desk, window seats, are all part of the room+ Don't like "gym" then Crunch Fitness is only $10. I didn't use Crunch since I just needed a treadmill. "Gym" is in a small space that fits just that, a treadmill, a stairmaster, handheld weights and a bench. There is a water cooler and an air conditioner. Super basic.+ Shelves by the doorway to throw your purchases, keys, etc. That came in handy.+ Great library in the lobby area. Esconce yourself in a leather space and read up.+ Great bed.+ Nice reception and doormen.And the not so +'s:- It's in Financial District. Not know for nightlife.
