But it is close to the Fulton St station which may be convenient but its weekend schedule sometimes means you have to go to another further station to make it.- Walls seem thin. I heard guests traipse down the hallway and sometimes even my neighbor. I can filter a lot out but it was a little annoying.Overall great accomodations. I'll return because of the discount for staying at a boutique hotel that's not terribly inconvenient.-

Stayed her with some friends for a weekend of eating and drinking. Got a very good price on priceline. Hotel is modern and clean. The bar downstairs is hip but not open super late so across the street at Harry's is a good bet for quick food and late night drinks. Overall a good experience. If you are looking to walk to NYC attractions this may not be your best bet (as it is in the financial district) but the subway is very close and easy to use to get to most spots.

I stayed here for a recent business trip and was impressed by the hotel. It is in the perfect location for people who are working in the financial district. The hotel feels like a stylish boutique option against the large traditioonal hotels, the lobby is set out like an Alpine lodge and the whole hotel feels quite cool. The only issue was that I originally boked the room next to the penthouse and the soundproofing was not good. However, the front desk moved me the next night and this room was much better.The rooms are comfortable and have all the modern technology you would expect. Overall a good hotel at reasonable rates.

We stayed for 2 days in the suite for a wedding at south street seaport. Very well decorated and clean room. The price was pretty pricey, but I suppose it's pretty much the same anywhere in that area. The staff was very nice and attentive. The only complaint I have is the breakfast available for $10.00 a person was aweful because there was not much to pick from and no silverware or napkins were available and the coffee was horrible. But I didn't stay there for the breakfast so really not hardly worth mentioning. I would stay there again.

We had a great time at Gild Hall. The service was wonderful. The rooms weren't large but it was to be expected in NYC. The decor of the hotel was very chic. The kids had a wonderful time playing checker in the cool lobby. The only unusual thing about the hotel was that you could see into the bathroom because the door was cloudy glass. We would definitely stay at any Thompson Hotel again.

Was so happy to visit the big apple !They gave me a room near the elevator on the 3rd floor ! (not my choice)Loved the room but problem with window between room and bathroom (no intimicy)On saturday night, they decided to play very loud music right beneath us, in the bar, until 4 AM ! We were not able to sleep all night ! What were they thinking ?

I stayed here to visit family, one of whom lived close by, which is why I chose it.Hotel itself is fine for what it is, a bit quirky and unsure of its identity, but fine for a two night stay. Problem was the bed, a narrow, lumpy, non-flexible or springy mattress on a platform, triggered already strained joints and back, causing a lot of pain. I called the front desk in the middle of the night to see if they had anything else. They didn't and didn't seem to care much about my predicament. Next night I was upgraded to a suite, which was truly lovely of them and in itself, but the bed was the same. No sleep for two nights. If this is not an issue, it is an adequate hotel. Good coffee in the breakfast area. Some staff very nice.

It seems that experience depends on the price you pay, as you pay more you expect more, but in NY more could mean a thousand dollars per nigth. If you have stayed in a hostel en NY you know the diference, all the other average hotels are similar to Gild. Gild is clean, friendly, close to tourist places, metro station, grocery stores if you want a botle of water and food places. Neighborhood is secure but many streets under repairment.

Gild Hall is a nice change from bland hotels with a nice interior lounge bar area, small cafe on the side giving a dark, winter feel. The rooms are good in lounge with comfy bed, but not sure it offers value for money.

A terrible experience all around. I arrived with my son and was given a room with one bed, when we requested a room with 2 beds, they said that we must have asked for one bed and any change would be considered an upgrade and cost more. oh, and if we'd booked through them directly instead of priceline, we would have gotten what we wanted. Off we went to our very small room across from the elevator and made do. 4 Star? the room felt like 2 star at best. Our phone didn't work. The attitude of the hotel staff was horrible with no attempt to be helpful. I would never stay there again. In addition to the horrible service, the parking cost a fortune and the restaurant options in the area are dismal. You would do better in a hostel.

The hotel is BORING. I have stayed at other Thompson Hotels that have great energy and cool rooms, Gild Hall has neither. The room was large, but very basic and boring in decor. The lobby was the same. I usually like to eat at the hotel's restaurant and have cocktails in the lounge, however I was there five days and had no desire to hang out there. I went a few blocks away to the W Downtown Living Room and had a great time in a fabulous space.

The Gild Hall has rooms of reasonable size, particularly in New York. This was my second stay at the Gild Hall. Although the rooms are reasonably sized by New York standards, they can be quite dark, particularly on low floors. I find the service here to be quite variable in quality. For example, I found it difficult to get through to room service on the phone. One day I had to call room service/the front desk 4 times before I was able to connect to room service. Room service did not pick up the phone, so the calls went to the front desk. The front desk promised at least two times that they would have room service call me, which did not occur until I had called 4 times. It took me over an hour to connect to room service and about 1.5 hours to get my food. This all occurred at approximately 3 pm in the afternoon.

This was a good hotel but the rooms felt old and a bit claustrophobic. On the plus side the bed was very comfortable and the service was excellent. We got this hotel on priceline and paid 170. We would not have been happy if we paid the full price.

The Hotel is clean and not bad for the cost. However, there is no room service in the mornings on the weekends. So if you want a cup of coffee (no coffee makers in the room) you will have to get up and go downstairs for it and pay 10.00 for one cup?!?. I also did not like that our bathroom was walled and doored with a kind of glass that you could see through. I don't know about everyone else but I really don't want my husband watching me use the restroom (awkward). The resturant was good the lunch menu comes with a glass of wine or beer. The one thing that I thought was so bad, is that you have to pay 10.00 for 24 hours of internet service.

Stayed there for four nights on a recent business trip. I am in NYC at least twice a month and have a great basis of comparison. The Gild Hall was one of the very best and I look forward to staying here again.Check-in was very efficient. Did not catch the name of the young lady on duty (blonde) but it had been a long time since I received such a warm welcome in NY. An excellent contract with the NYC W Hotel where all I received was a snarl and a room the size of a closet!The room was quite large and distinctively styled. Bathroom was also large and everything was clean. On my first night, the manager sent up a nice bottle of sake with a welcoming note. Received a plate of cookies on the third night with another note asking if I was enjoying my stay.Speaking of the manager, I was in the lobby early one morning waiting for the elevator when I saw what must have been the manager walking around the hotel shaking hands with his staff. That speaks volumes about him!By far, one of my best stays in NYC. Thank you!

I stayed at Gild Hall a couple months back in Feb '11. I'm a NYC resident who, after a catastrophe at my apartment, was pleasantly surprised by the warm service I received at Gild Hall. I booked online through Priceline so I was not expecting much when I arrived a little disheveled from my day. The young lady who checked me in was extremely pleasant and very empathetic when she asked as to the reason for my stay. I was given a room on the 11th floor, which was a smoking floor. I was a little hesitant when I stepped off the elevator as I did not want to get into a room that smelled of an ashtray. However, the room was spotless and did not smell one bit of smoke. The room was also very large by NYC standards. I believe I was put into a Deluxe King, so a slight upgrade.Due to my situation of not knowing when my apartment would be ready again, I resorted to booking an extra night a few days for a total of 4 nights. Since I did each through Priceline, I had to go down to the desk to do a quick check-in process each time, but every person I dealt with was exceptionally friendly. Housekeeping was also extremely efficient. I left the hotel late a couple days (I work from home) after a couple knocks on the door from housekeeping and expected to return later to find that my room had yet to be serviced, but was pleasantly surprised each time. I think I may have had to call down once, but it was clean within an hour of my request. The only qualm I had was that I use multiple devices to connect to the internet, and Gild Hall charges for WiFi access. However, after stating my confusion (or clutziness) for not reading the full script, the gentleman who checked me out the final day refunded the "duplicate" WiFi charges for each day, really going above what I expected.Overall, I enjoyed my "forced vacation" at Gild Hall. During an extremely stressful time, they allowed me a place to escape and relax. I would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone I know that's traveling into the city or just looking for a one-night "getaway."

We stayed at Gild Hall this past weekend and have few complaints. The location is average, I have never stayed in he Financial District and found it is not my favorite neighborhood. However, the hotel is very convenient to the subway and I'd definitely stay here again. Other reviewers mentioned problems controlling the temperature in their rooms, but our room had a thermostat that adjusted easily and we were very comfortable. My one complaint would be the corrugated glass bathroom wall and door. It did not afford much privacy as you can see more than just the outline of someone sitting on the toilet! It was fine since I was traveling with my husband, but would not share a room with anyone else at this hotel! Overall we had a pleasant stay and felt the price we paid on priceline was fair. We would definitely stay here again.

It was very disappointing to see that a hotel of the standard of the Thompson Group had personnel that did not know how to provide service.In virtualy all aspects of service, especially at the front desk and at the bar, we found a very haughty and unhelpful service.No one seemed to care

...after I had a great stay at the Gild Hall last year, I booked it again and was looking forward to it - which was a big mistake. Although I booked a Deluxe King with high ceilings, I was assigned to a small room with low ceiling. In addition to the low ceiling and the black carpet, the room was facing the very near by neighbour builing, with the result of a dark, depressive room! This can't be called stylish. After a complaint at the (quite unfriendly and not helpful) front desk and 5 minutes of arguing, they "upgraded" me "complimentary" to my booked Deluxe King, that had at least the high ceilings and some light. BUT: the carpet was dirty and stained, the desk to was stained and not cleaned, the flower vase was empty (although it was filled with water), the towels were ragged and dirty and there were no proper bathroom amenities. After another complaint they changed the bathroom, but without any apologies...Besides you have to get used to the see-through bathroom door/wall, with the toilet basically next to the bed. This too is not stylish!I would not rcommend to stay here, unless you get one of the rooms facing East.I would not recommend to stay here, if you expect a 4*-hotel, that it used to be.

The Gild Hall is a clean, comfortable, cozy, but not particularly luxurious, hotel in excellent finanical district location. The front desk, bell, and bar staff were all friendly and helpful. Room was NY small, but clean. Sleep quality was good with quiet rooms, nice/newer bedding, and good ventilation. Bath is also small, but functional with nice fixtures, good bath products and decent water pressure. Small fitness facilities located on 3 (?) of 18 floors - each with one Cybex treadmill and one elipitical.

and I cannot turn on the heat!!! this place is really nice looking, but to food in the mini bar is stale and dusty...which pales in comparision to my freezing here! I cannot adjust the heater in my room. The staff seemed nice and the lobby is great, but unless you love the cold, do not stay here.
user_name:
Sakineh S
New York City, New York

review_body: Great hotel in many ways - Maria on reception was fantastic, rooms generally very good standard, really easy to get to on subway from downtown, quiet location, good value for money on Priceline. On the down side I agree with the other reviews, a four star hotel should not be charging $10 a day for internet use. Unfortunately it seems Hector the duty manager's customer service has seen better days, but aside from that I would still definitely stay again.

When you check-in it looks like a nice place to stay but that's not true.When I first arrived to the reception, the lady did not paid attention to my troubles. You need to use a card to take the elevator, like to open the room door. Everybody knows that sometimes it's not easy to use these techniques. The lady only checked my card and looked at me like I was a martian. Once on the bedroom, I've tried to connect my laptop to Internet, troubles again. I had to comeback downstairs 2 times and ask again for my net access. After a 10$ surcharge I realized that the speed of the connection was like in 1995 (slower than turtles doing athletics). I decided to sleep and forget all this things. Today I woke up and it was snowing outdoors, I tried to switch on the heating but it doesn' t work... 120$ for this? Unbelievable.... I'll never visit anymore hotels of this chain. Spend your money in a best NYC place!

The good things about this hotel are still in place - but despite the various comments on this site and the staff saying "we have forwarded a number of similar comments to the management" - so are the negatives.Despite the excellent Amy moving on from the front desk, those left behind continue to be helpful and always have a smile for you - even when you arrive to check in grumpy at 2 am having suffered the worst of the US's immigration system.Working in the financial district I just need something clean comfortable and central and the hotel suits that purpose, and for NYC, price is fine.Even if you are not needing to be in the financial district the location is - despite what others have said - also fine, as Fulton street subway is two/three blocks away and has a number of lines to uptown. You do need to know your way around the city though - not the best option for a first timer. However, the continuing charge of $10 (a day, but also for 5 minutes) for internet use is a disgrace. No provision of coffee and tea making facilities, and definitely no daily cookies now (see my and other reviews) are real downers. Considering the reasonable prices, if they charged an extra $10 a day, and included these three options, very few would complain about the price, but would be delighted to find all the extras "free".Oh, and breakfast at weekends is a joke at $10. Again charge a little more maybe, but include in price (the hotel is really reasonable at weekends due to location).Weekday breakfast is fine, but so, so slow.Still a recommendation, but could get itself up to a 5 with a few simple improvements

I spent one night here with a friend. Booked through Hotwire, it's a great value for the money. The hotel's decor is unique for NYC, but the rooms are spacious, the bathrooms have modern, clean fixtures and the bed was very comfortable. The location (in the financial district) is only dissappointing if you aren't expecting to walk or cab anywhere. We knew where the hotel was before we booked and spent a nice half-hour walking to midtown. What better way to get a feel for a city? The service was lacking- we didn't get our requested wake up call (though the alarm clock in the room worked), and one front desk woman was a bit snippy when I asked if they had alternatives to the lavendar soap to which I am allergic. All in all, a nice little boutique hotel that suited my NYC needs.

Purchase thru Priceline. Touted as 4-stars. At best a 2.5 star hotel along the likes of Holiday Inn. Inconvenient location for a tourist. Room small with little frills. Bed appeared not made when we arrived and had to request a re-make. Gym was dispersed on three separate floors with one each of elliptical/treadmill and free weights. This hotel is ideal for the business traveler to Wall Street who spends little time at the hotel.

My wife and I stayed there for New Year's eve. We had a nice stay, but we felt that this boutique hotel was not quite as nice as others we have enjoyed in the city. The hotel has a trendy feel to it, an interesting decor, the room was nice but a little dark for our taste, the bed comfortable. The bathroom is also nice but had a few problems. The shower was very nice but we had to play with the stopper (and eventually pull it off without being able to put it back on) to get rid of the water at our feet. More importantly, the toilet was not functioning properly and got clogged. Finally, the bathroom with faux glass walls is nice but if if someone goes into the bathroom at night it lights up the entire room.Be aware that the bar downstairs (next to lobby) appears to be very popular, but perhaps it was only due to New Year's Eve. When we came back to the hotel around 1 AM, the lobby was crowded and the party was raging! we were happy to have a room high up.I point out the problems we encountered but do not mean to suggest that the place was bad. It has character, it is in a quiet location close to the subway , the staff is very nice, and the problems mentioned earlier can be fixed.

I visited Gild Hall because I've stayed at the Thompson Hotel in Washington DC and loved it. One of the employees at their DC location recommended it to me. My boyfriend and I were visiting New York for the weekend and the staff truly made us feel like royalty. The front desk managers, Maria and Hector were exceptionally attentive and hospitable. Natalie, the concierge, is sensational! She helped us make dinner reservations, buy tickets, the whole nine yards. This small boutique hotel sets itself apart from the rest with its outstanding customer service and attention to detail. After each day, all the employees welcomed us back using our names. Even the bell staff remembered our names! One final note: spring for the upgrade to the Studio King - the raised ceiling makes you forget you are in the big, bustling city. All around, the accommodations are GREAT!!! We will be back.

A standard room and a standard NYC hotel experience. Located near 4&5 and 2&3 subway lines giving pretty good access to the rest of the city. Great for business in downtown NY as most major offices are nearby. The room is standard by NY standards. Don't expect to make coffee or iron your shirt in your room. Neither are standard nor complimentary. I appreciated a copy of the WSJ every morning complimentary. Altough, most business oriented hotels are doing this. Be very cautious as the walls are PAPER THIN! And I mean to the point that the conversation next door sounds like its in your room. I didn't appreciate the 12:30am wake up to a neighbor vomitting in his bathroom. All in all an okay stay. I would probably not recomend just on the basis of no privacy with the paper thin walls. I'm also not a fan when the manager doesn't respond to the trip advisor complaints. A bit pricey midweek for this type of hotel in downtown NY.

Western Lodge motif in Lobby/Restaurant which carries into the rooms. Hallways bright red w/ gloss white trim, which I found to be garish. Room small, but reasonably tasteful. I wouldn't want to try and work from the small campaign desk, surprising noting location in the financial district. Very friendly staff. $10 continental breakfast on the weekends. Generally quiet due to location. If you had to stay here, no problem. I wouldn't make an effort to do so. The whole Lodge theme while trying to be hip falls flat. I don't mean to be tough on this place, but it bills itself as a four star. I've stayed at four stars and they all had an elegance and appeal this place lacks. Again it does everything just fine, but if your a leisure traveler and springing for four stars, I think you can find places that are a lot more special. Yes, I would recommend if you get a deal.

We stayed here with friends for a weekend in the city. It is in the financial district, which made it very quiet on a Sat and Sun. However, it is a short walk to South Street Seaport and Ground Zero. Room was a deluxe so was a bit larger than usual, bathroom very nice. One draw back (which I had read about on reviews) was the heat/air unit. It cranks on and off and is somewhat loud. The breakfast was $10 all eat continental and was OK not great. The best part was we arrived at hotel around 10am Sat and our rooms were ready. How nice! The staff was friendly. Our valet parking was right across the street so we got our car in minutes of check out.
Great find in Wall Street area. Walk to Bankruptcy Court. Nice bar. Reasonably priced restaurant.

Pros:• Large Room• Great value for the price• Nice decor - cool upscale/hunting lodge theme (but not cheesy - very well done)• Clean• ModernCons:• The hotel bar defaults to the high end booze. We ordered two vodka crans and it was $30• The financial district is pretty dead on the weekends

Even if the room was $99 I wouldn't stay here again. I'll try to distill a long story into a few salient items.1) The building's HVAC system is set up so that only air or heat will work at one time - i.e. the building needs to switch to heat downstairs in the boiler room. Well think about the Fall when it's warm during the day and cool at night - since the hotel was still set up for A/C there was NO HEAT! And no way to get any heat. Shivering in the room...2) Service is poor for a hotel of this standard. Was treated curtly by just about everyone.3) Rooms are a disappointment - they have a few interesting touches, but a lot of empty white walls to stare at. Felt like I was in a big white box. Very uncomfortable.4) No taxis available -- some others have commented on this and said it was no big deal you just walk 2-3 blocks. Well imagine doing that in a pouring rainstorm or a snowstorm? That becomes a major problem.5) Location -- terrible even for this part of town.The lobby bar was the only highlight of the place, but not enough to supercede the above points. Next time I stay downtown I'll go to the Andaz.

Pros:- Location is quiet, peaceful, close to a grocery store and pharmacies, close to subway. We read in one of the reviews that the closest subway stop is closed, and we did see one Fulton St. entrance that is closed, but there are other entrances that are just a few blocks away from the hotel. - Rooms are very nicely appointed and elegant. Our view from the 16th floor still looked right into another apartment building, but it was fine. Bed was very comfortable, decor was nice, fair amount of space. We were concerned about the semi-transparent bathroom wall thing, but it was really a non-issue. You can't really see a thing.- Price was right!! We booked a superior king room for $215/night (on hotelbook.com) for Labor Day weekend. Where else can you find reasonable rates AND quality in NYC??Cons:- Location is a little out of the way, and nothing nearby is open late, but if you've read the reviews and looked at a map, you should be expecting this. And on the plus side, it is much, much quieter than staying somewhere close to the sights.- The complimentary continental breakfast was a little pitiful. Sad selection and zero table service (couldn't find a napkin, glass of water, or server anywhere in sight). Skip!! - Housekeeping was a little sloppy. We had a couple towels that didn't look very clean, and the soap dish was dirty when we arrived. Not a big deal, but not up to the standard I would have expected, given the rest of the hotel.- Charging $10/day for the internet, esp in the business district, is lame. - No iron in the room - again, for a business district hotel, lame.A note on bedbugs: there are none here, at least as far as we could tell. I checked bedbugregistry.com before we went, and someone had written that they had seen bedbugs in their bathroom at this hotel. I was really worried about this and read tripadvisor reviews obsessively to see if anyone had commented on this, but no one had. When we checked in, my husband and I stripped the bed - checked the comforter, sheets, and mattress, and didn't see anything. We stayed two nights and have been home for a week and don't seem to have brought back any travelers with us. *Whew* I was VERY concerned about this. I told the front desk when we were checking out that I had read about a bedbug complaint online, and he said a few weeks ago, one guest did complain about bedbugs and that they sent up staff to check it out but didn't find anything (or did he say that there might have been bugs, but they were not bedbugs?). I recommended that the hotel dispute the complaint on bedbugregistry.com if it had been determined to be untrue, but he didn't seem too concerned. Anyway, I'm sure plenty of hotels deny any type of bedbug problem, so I appreciated that he was honest about someone reporting it. Just wanted to put this out there, in case anyone else is as paranoid as me! :) Overall, the next time we're in NYC, we would stay here again. A great hotel with fantastic rates, this place is a steal and one of the best deals in NYC.
user_name:
theTraveLees
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: We chose the Gild Hall Hotel because we love the Financial District of Manhattan. Since 1999 we have be coming to NYC on a regular basis because our children were students at New York University. Eleven years ago nothing was happening in this district. We stayed downtown because it was cheaper and quieter than other areas. The Battery Park area has/had all the things we loved: quiet, scenery, unique shops, and so much more. When we arrived at the Gild Hall Hotel, we were greeted with a warm welcome. An associate greeted us with immediate service. We wanted the valet parking service which meant he took our luggage out of the car, put it on a cart, directed us to the desk, took the luggage to our room, showed us the features of the room, brought us ice, and parked our car in a safe spot! All the same man! Not ten different people to tip, which gets very confusing. At the check-in desk we met Kelli Phillips. She was amazing! It was our fortieth wedding anniversary, and immediately she upgraded us to a beautiful suite! Our room had a living room with a huge leather sofa, two comfortable chairs, a glass top coffee table an HD LG TV that was fabulous. We also had a kitchenette with a coffee maker, sink, microwave and a small mini-bar fridge. We were able to store our personal items in this fridge.Our bedroom had a fabulous king-sized bed which had very comfortable sheets and pillows. It also had a very large HD LG TV. The bedroom was so comfortable! The bathroom had a huge shower, double sinks, many towels, and CO Bigelow hair and body products. It was awesome!Kelli seemed to be our contact person. I guess she must work 24/7. Don’t know how that works. She seemed to always be there; greeting us and making sure our stay was fantastic! If I needed anything she was there! Great stay! Can’t wait to go back! Kelli was amazing! “Surround yourself with good people and let them do their jobs.” Obliviously the motto of the Gild Hall Hotel!

We had a 4 day convention in Manhattan at the Javits Convention Center and stayed at Gild Hall due to a package air and hotel deal on Expedia. This boutique-style hotel is located in the center of the Business District. PROS:- Incredibly professional service and hospitable staff. This staff stands out from even more high end hotels that we've stayed at as their guest service was impeccable. Warm and welcoming, yet professional and polite. Can I say professional, once again. It is not often that one comes across such well trained, genuine staff in the service industry.- Unique design/decor- Easy access to the subway, one block away.- Comfortable, clean beds.CONS:- Awkward to get to Javits. Taxi ride cost us $13-14 each way every day! Many taxi drivers claimed to not know this hotel and had difficulty finding it tucked away in the Business District. Often had to walk a block or two to find a main artery that taxis frequented as they do not pass by the hotel regularly. Only $6 to/from SoHo.- Not really a touristy hotel as most tourist sites are not within walking distance.- Small rooms and bathroom (no countertop space at all).- Aging finishing. Needs touch-ups on walls, furniture, doorways, etc.- Had to pay $10 for internet per day. In this day and age and in the Business District this should be included in the room cost. If you are primarily going to be located in the Business District, you can't go wrong for service at this hotel. If you are going for pleasure/tourism, I would recommend staying closer to /in Midtown or Times Square area as many more sites are easily walked to and easily accessible. Definitely had higher taxi costs this time that previous visits due to location and wasted time moving about the city to/from here.

I am writing before my trip. I had a major booking problem. I needed to be downtown for a few nights and if I liked the hotel was going to extend my stay for 7 nights. However, after booking a room, I found out I couldn't add a roll-away bed for my son. He would need it for only 2 nights. "Fire" laws were cited. I asked for a room with twin beds. "That's $50 more per night." The online booking agent would not and could not help, refusing to change the reservation to another hotel. Apparently, this hotel insists on more money for their twin bed rooms, which are cited as larger. I have therefore booked the remainder of my stay at another hotel. Again, my comments are based on booking and beds.

For my business trips to NY financial district, I used to stay at the Hilton Millenium, but then the inevitable cut backs from HO surfaced and I had to find an alternative. My NY office booked me the Gild Hall and I have now stayed there four times - for 2-3 weeks at a time.My first reaction was that the reception area and bar reminded me of an English country town hotel.The smiling receptionist (Amy) on the first occasion I walked in on a snowy and freezing February evening warmed me up immediately, and I don't think I have ever met such a friendly receptionist crew. The bar staff were eqaully friendly.The rooms do vary, some are a bit small and others are - by NY standards - almost massive, but they all seem to be the same price - I suppose corporate rate determines that.Downsides. Breakfast can be very slow (insufficient staff) and is not cheap. The weekend continental breakfast is a joke - there are however a number of ok places nearby at less than half the price. The bar (ex the 5-8 happy hour) is expensive even for NY.As others have suggested, the $10 charge for WIFI use is a disgrace.As one other mentioned, the brownies on the pillow disappeared this year, but I mentioned this to Amy, and that evening................brownies!!

Stayed here a couple of times on business in the last year. Overall very positive experiences. It's certainly at the boutique end of the scale with v. tastefully furnished rooms of a good size - bordering on generous for NYC. Bathrooms are particularly nicely done, with good freebies. Only downsides from my perspective is that the bar is very small and very noisy (when you arrive inn the evenings you feel like you've arrived at a private party) and there isn't really any room service to speak of. It's pricey, but you're paying for an upmarket stay in a prime Wall Street location.

We booked a Double Queen bed room in Gild Hall hotel, and we were 3 people. The service was not satisfactory because they even did not provide us with enough Shampoos, Soap. Every we were about to asked them to put these items for us. Also, the size of the room was to small in comparison to the standard of other hotels. However, the place was too convenient to all downtown areas. The breakfast was not included and the price of breakfast, lunch, and dinner was too expensive. The most awful thing was the speed of internet, and you have to pay 10$ per night for the internet. Seriously the speed was awful and comparable to disconnection.

1. It is true that the hotel isn't in midtown, but it is right near a few subway stops, that take you anywhere in the city. 2. The rooms are small in general, but with high ceilings.3. The furnishings are slightly dated, but in NY who spends allot of time in the room4. The elevators need to be revamped. 5. The male concierge wasn't so nice and helpful, however there was an Indian woman who works behind the front desk who was so delightful and helpful. Sorry I don't have a better way of describing her. 6. All in all the staff was great.7. The rooms were spotless. The maid service fabulous.8. Horrible workout center.9. The weirdest thing was the bathroom. They are see through. Going to the bathroom can be a bit weird. 10. Overall if the price was right I would stay here again, but wouldn't go out of my way.

When we booked this hotel it was sitting at the top of preferred NYC hotels in this area...Photos on the site are among the most misleading I have encountered. We booked two Deluxe rooms, ( one up from the base accommodation) they were both VERY small, we could not walk passed the end of the bed without bumping into the furnitureAccommodation was dark and dingy, the bathroom has a dappled glass wall that faces the sleeping area. In both our rooms the electronic keys failed to open the doors every time we returned for 5 days, ( this was apparently because we kept them too close to our phones, not a problem at prior or subsequent accommodation in NYC or anywhere else...), the air conditioning was very noisy, the restaurant was closed for breakfast the first morning because of a wedding and the meagre offering upstairs at the bar was entirely unsatisfactory, the bar stopped serving drinks at 11.00 pm on Saturday night because of some staffing snafu...The entrance is interesting but the rest is just dated. the staff were generally terrific but they are dealing with a hotel billing itself as modern and trendy when it is really just tired.Note too that it is not always easy to get a cab from her if that is what you need.

Beautiful hotel, much more interesting location than the usual midtown hotels. Huge room, great design, great amenities. Somewhat weird design choice with the bathroom - it's basically a glass cube, so when a person uses it in the middle of the night it lights up & illuminates the whole room - usually waking up the other person. Staff was hit or miss; some were nice, some the usual NYC oblivious & snooty. The one serious problem we had with them was we were waiting for a package to be delivered, and even though we alerted them to this daily they managed to miss it & send it back. To us this was a major problem, they didn't seem to particularly care. In spite of this, all in all a very good hotel, fantastic value for NYC.

Sure the hotel is quiet and in a great location for people who have commitments in the financial district. In other respects though, Gild Hall failed to live up to expectations. While the hunting lodge motif may work in the public areas, it does not in the bedrooms. Some may consider the design 'hip', but we found the colour schemes gloomy. Our room was not particularly clean and had several burnt out lightbulbs - an indication of lack of housekeeping attention.What passed for continental breakfast was a joke. A limited selection of cereals and pastries - the latter stale - and a small bowl of fresh fruit. Customer service was mediocre and inattentive. If this is a reflection of Thompson hotel standards, then our recommendation is to think twice before reserving.

Stayed at the Gild Hall for 4 nights and apart from the housekeeping staff forgetting small things such as emptying our bin and our window not being fixed after letting reception know after the first night, it is a cool hotel. The rooms are very spacious compared to others we have stayed at in NY. As the hotel is not on a main road it is also a lot quieter than staying on say 5th Avenue or closer to some of the main attractions. We didn't have breakfast included in our stay, but there is an abundance of places around to eat at for all budgets. The air conditioning is also a bit loud but was good to have it since the temp reach the 90s! Overall it was a very relaxed hotel and we enjoyed staying there. Not such a great location if you want to be in the thick of it as Times Square is a good 40 blocks away. We would recommend this hotel.

I stayed here with my husband ( he was on holiday) and a good friend of mine who was also out here for work. The hotel was lovely, We had a room on the 17th floor. 162 which was lovely although my friends room on the 17th floor room 176 was twice the size. The rooms were modern and nicely furnished. The only complaint was no mirror over the dressing table. There was a flat screen TV instead which my husband was happy about.The loo seat was chipped but they now had soft closing lids which must have been a result of the original lids. The shower was good but could have a been a bit more powerful.All the staff was lovely and friendly. (Although one lady did give us the wrong directions to Lord and Taylor...best place for shoes in NY) And the doorman was gorgeous.Working on Broadway this hotel was perfect. No more than 5 minutes walk. If I was here on holiday it is a bit of a pain as other than century 21 no other major shops are close by but the subways are easy to use if you remember up town and downtown. Good places to eat near by though and I can recommend Mad dog and stones which is a fab mexican about 7 minutes away.Lovely hotel and I would stay there again and I will be giving it a good review for work.

I booked this hotel on Priceline for an anniversary trip. I ended up having an important meeting the first morning I arrived and was anxious about being able to look rested beforehand. My husband and I were taking the redeye out and arriving early. The front desk was able to check us in early and met all the requests I made for the room when I called ahead. All of the staff were extremely friendly. I am not a fan of antlers but otherwise loved the decor - the bathrooms are gorgeous and the beds are very comfortable. My only disappointments were: they no longer put brownies on your pillow (that was so unique and awesome!), they do not give lotion as part of the toiletry set, and housekeeping was a bit noisy in the mornings. Loved the hotel though and would stay again for sure. Gild Hall is in the Financial District - so not the most convenient for dining in the evening but it is located near many different lines - so very easy to get uptown for shopping and eating.

I've stayed at Gild Hall a few times now and find it a quiet retreat. While it's not the best location in NY it's always well priced, rooms in the upper floors are large and comfortable by NY standards and staff are very nice. My only gripe is NO free WIFI (which is typical of Thompson Hotels) and this needs to change. At $10 per day, figure this into your calculations when deciding on price alone.

I stayed here recently during a visit to NYC for a friends birthday. While the weather was absolutely horrible, the Gild Hall offered a decent place to get out of the rain. Finding the (pretty small) hotel was a bit of a challenge due to the location, and when we arrived there was no one to Valet our car, and their was only one staff member working the front desk. Once we established that our car would be parked, everything involving check-in/out went fine. The room was on the small side, but was comfortable and nicely appointed...had a cool "millionares hunting lodge" vide. Beds were decent, and everything was clean. I would give this hotel 4 stars, but after checkout we were billed several mystery fees, which ended up adding up unacceptably. The amount wasn't large enough to waste time fighting, but were annoying enough to make me consider other options the next time I'm in NYC.

This is my second stay at Gild Hall and I do not recall the rooms being so small (even smaller than the rooms at the W Hotel or by typical NY standards). The room was clean and provided what I need, but difficult to relax given the size. On the plus side, the location is very convenient for Wall Street business.

Not only did things not work: remote control for tv; door keys; reading lights; air conditioner and the phone but nobody really cared. They made you feel that you were inconveniencing them by reporting the problems. The location is terrible if you are in NY to see anything and it is really hard to find even after you have been there a few times. Cab drivers never even heard of the street. . They say they have fitness center which is nothing more than a musty room with a couple of machines. Only place I have ever stayed in NY where they couldn't even tell you where to get a NY Times. I wouldn't stay here again if it was free. I am writing from the hotel now and can't wait to leave tomorrow.

We arrived on a Friday for a weekend stay in New York. We know our way around the City well enough not to be intimidated by staying so far Downtown, in the Financial district, and so we decided to try the Gild Hotel. The weeKend rate was under $200, which is always a pleasant find in NYC We took the train into the City, and found it easy to just hop on the subway and make our way there. The Hotel was only about three blocks from the subway stop - very convenient.The reception staff could not have been more friendly when we arrived. Amy, in particular, took great care of us. We had a standard room, which she upgraded. She went out of her way to help us with a place to eat lunch and offer other advice. The rest of the staff during our stay were warm and friendly, always checking in with how we were doing.The hotel itself is in a very quiet location. The rooms are designed in such a way that there is limited window area, but it really wasn't a problem. The room size was typical for New York, a bit on the small side, but more than enough room. The smallish lobby opens into a reataurant and bar area, with a "library" on the second floor, all very stylish.Although the Financial district can be somewhat limited in restaurant choices, it is getting better, and Tribeca, with many restaurants, is several blocks away. We walked both nights, in spite of cold spring nights! The only challenge can be the subway schedule during the weekend. However, there are several stops within a few blocks walking distance, and the Fulton Street stop seems to run somewhat regularly.In short, we have found a new home in New York City, and would highly recommend this Hotel. I would not recommend the location to someone who is visiting for the first time and looking to see the sights such as Times Square which are located in Midtown. But, if you know your way around the City - definitely!

Overall, Gild Hall makes a pretty nice impression. It has definite style with a great looking lobby. The concierge was helpful in pointing out the best nearby pizza. It is located near Fulton Street which is connected to many subway lines but is pretty far downtown. The bathroom was nice though a couple tiles looked scratched and there were chips in the toilet. The bed was super comfortable though! Overall it was great but I don't know if it lives up to the price.

Just got back from a two-night stay at Gild Hall. Found a great rate online and decided to give another part of Manhattan a try rather than the usual Time Square. Gild Hall is as described online. Modern but nostalgic, cool but funky. I really enjoyed my stay. My room was on the third floor and had no view. Actually it was pretty dim even during the day as it looked out on an alley. That was fine by me as my nighttime activities made a late morning sleep a necessity. The room was more than large enough for one and would probably be good for two. I wouldn't say the black carpet was low quality as some have commented - it just shows everything right away. The bed was great - super comfy and the sheets luxurious. Never heard a peep in the night or morning. The room was warm until I found the thermostat and turned it from 'warm' to 'cool'. The bathroom was modern and nice, though the shower nobs were a bit confusing at first. Good water pressure. Staff at the front was always super polite and helpful. PLEASE NOTE: The nearest subway station (Fulton St) is under construction thru 2010 on the weekends and is closed Saturday and Sunday. The next closest subway stop is City Hall, which is a good 10 minute walk. If you're a weekend visitor it makes the hike to the hotel less convenient, especially after a long day of walking around town. Your subway line choices are also limited. But for the price it's still a good deal. I would recommend, especially if you're in town to shop at Century 21 and do things other than Broadway shows and don't mind a bit of a walk to things.

I travel to New York City about four times a month and have stayed in my fair share of hotels ranging from the 5-star Plaza to the 3-star Tudor Hotel. This is by far one of the best experiences with a hotel in New York. From the moment you are greeted by the door man you notice something different. The lobby is reminiscent of a cabin in Colorado. This is a very "man's man" hotel. Dark woods. Low lighting. Thick wood tables. Low level seating. Shelves of books. The nearby bar demands that you come and have a drink before hitting the streets of New York. The lobby and the attendants assisting you with check-in are not prissy. Yet, there is a great sense of customer service. Different from chain hotels, the employees even partake in being unique wearing trendy clothes that differs from stuffy, old concierge suits at other places. At night, the intimate lobby is filled with hip and young patrons conversing with each other enjoying the ambiance. There are no more than 10 rooms per floor. The rooms are decorated reminiscent of the lobby. Dark woods and rich browns. The headboard of the bed is the length of the wall upholstered in leather. The bathroom while somewhat small is clean bright and tiled in clear tiles. The brown marble floor gives it a clean elegance. The room has a huge brass chandelier that could be found in mountain ski lodge.I would not recommend this hotel if you are heading to New York City for the first time. It is located in the Financial District. It is less touristy then other parts of the city. Instead, if you are returning to New York and want to be amidst trendy residents who probably work in the skyscrapers of the surrounding banks. Or if you want to eat at small, contemporary restaurants with exceptional service and innovate menus catering to the discerning young professional. Then this place is for you. The area empties out after 5pm on a weekday. I believe that is a huge plus. The people that remain in the area are not tourists, instead its the residents. At times, you have the streets to yourself and in New York City that is surprisingly relaxing feeling.  Gild Hall has become my number 1 choice while in NYC.

...although when booking the Guild Hall for two nights over the weekend I was a bit nervous because I was not sure what to expect. After staying there I can highly recommend to everybody to stay at the Gild Hall: 1.) it is a very stylish hotel with a unique design 2.) our room (18th. floor) was huge, clean, with a great bed and very nice bath amenities 3.) the staff was extremely friendly and helpful 4.) the Financial District is my new favourite in NYC - it offers a great and safe neighbourhood experience with restaurants, stores and the subway nearby - not too touristy, but still close to Brooklyn Bridge, Southstreet Seaport, China Town, Wall Street, etc. 5.) great value.I'm loking forward to come back!

Stayed here for one night. We were very pleased. We started off with a cocktail at the hotel bar, the libertine and it knocked my socks off. Note: manhattan $16! vodka tonic $12. a bit ridiculous, still we felt great once we entered our room.The rooms are well decorated and very chic looking. No complaints there. Good quality bed linens, nice king sized bed and the room was not too tiny by new york standards. I like the bathroom sink and tile, everything looked new and very clean in our room.We got our room for $112 off of Quikbook, and consider it a great value.Only complaint was when i called concierge for toothpaste at 1 am. The woman said, we have it but it will take 10 minutes to bring it up. I waited 20 and then called her back to say never mind, we were going to sleep. she just said "ok", not "oh im sorry we are so busy right now".Otherwise it was a smooth stay, and very quiet all night, however we did hear one man's moans at about 8 am, but that can happen at any hotel full of young lovers!

Great location if you are working downtown or you just want to get away from the general noise of NYC. Brilliant staff, v helpful, responded to all requests quickly. Good bar that has a happy hour from 5-8pm. Downside is that the rooms are nothing special, quite small, dingy, not helped by black carpet. Window blinds that don't shut property, tiny bathrooms and actually overall quite cheap looking with a tartan blanket on the bed and faux leather headboard. I think the prices are v. steep for what you get and in that part of town I think there are better options. One thing I couldn't get over was that if you wanted an ethernet cable you had to buy one ! I wouldn't not stay again, but it wouldn't be top choice.

We arrived early in the morning after an all night flight and were greeted and given helpful information about the city. The staff directed us towards a restaurant to eat breakfast and then after we went out sightseeing we came back and our room was ready early. Overall we loved the staff - they were extremely approachable & had some great information about the city that was really helpful. They were always warm & courteous even when we acted like tourist with some ridiculous questions. We had an amazing time in NYC and contribute much of this to our delightful stay at the Gild. If we went back to NYC we wouldn't think twice before staying here again!

A marvelous hotel in every way except location. The lobby has a distinct character that mixes ultra-hip with classic old fashioned charm - featuring a cross between an alpine ski lodge and an ivy league library. Terrific value for the amenities. Only drawback is its location down in the Financial District... but it's really just a short subway ride away from the rest of the city.
Although a little too far downtown for my business meeting(s), I had no regrets about staying at this cool boutique locale. Typical small NYC hotel rooms, but a nice lobby area and good staff

stayed one night, booking just two days before arriving, and had a bill of under $200!. What a price for a fantastic hotel in a fantastic location.Location... great location just one block off the main streets. (some women travelers may be concerned, but not that bad). Cabs were easy to find.. although my cabbie needed directions to get there.Building... with only 9 rooms on each floor, you can imagine that this is small... but the lobby is nicely appointed, the bar cosy. Everything is tastefully decorated.. with little nooks to visit. And quiet! No sirens or crashing garbage trucks heard from my room. Unbelievable difference from my last visit to any big city. Rooms... who says they're small??!! I've had smaller rooms at HoJo and Ramada. Decorated in ebony wood and dark leather, the room is, again, tastefully decorated. a large 46" flatscreen TV is a nice touch. I was in the "smallest" room, so the desk/dresser wasn't very deep, but I could still get some work done after dinner. Yes, the translucent plastic wall between the room and the washroom could put people off. Having the toilet just next to the wall facing into the room doesn't help. Don't plan on breakfast at the hotel... $15 light breakfast through room service could be replaced by walking two - three blocks for some lovely French pastries. At first I was taken aback by the $10 charge for internet access (and no WIFI).. but then I remembered the price of the room.In the evening, there is a wide range of restaurants and bars... I was there on Thursday so they were all well populated (Do New Yorkers ever go home?).All in all, a fantastic stay. I see why London Times rated the Gild #68 in the top 100 hotels IN THE WORLD. (note this wasn't top boutique hotels).Definitely planning a trip back!

Very nice and hotel staff were very accommodating. Nicely decorated, very comfortable (and roomy for NYC standards) rooms and very private. I am still questioning the people who wrote reviews about the bathroom see through doors...... what is your problem?? Had never booked with a boutique hotel in NYC before this and now I will never go back to the large chain hotels. This was a quiet place to come back to after a long busy day.
Hotel is fantastic and great value. Great beds, awesome flat screen tv. Very convienient to the subway.

A great, quiet location if you plan on using the MTA (and why wouldn't you). Nice comfortable beds and super clean. Close enough to walk to Chinatown for that late night meal. The only potential drawback is the glass separating the bathroom. It is by no means transparent but not quite opaque either. If you're traveling with that not-so-intimate partner, you may be privy to a little more than expected, At the right price, a great stay.

We felt spoiled by ALL the staff for the whole long weekend. The front office was just the best and every staff member you met walking around the place just couldn't do enough for you.The receptionist said as we arrived from a shopping trip: "Let us take all your shopping to your room while you relax in the bar."When was the last time you heared these perfect words at ANY hotel lately?We upgraded to one of the suites found at the end of each floor, it was huge and SO comfortable. The rooms were large (for NY) but we just decided to have the extra comfort and the bed, bedding - just everything was 1st class. Some people might find the long walk from bed to the loo a problem - we just laughed and said the exercise was good for you!I am a bit of a grumpy OM and can find fault in everything - but we couldn't find anything to complain about. The decor wont appeal to all but then I am not too keen on curry shop swags and tails and gloved butlers - but Gild Hall is just so comfy and relaxed you have to like it.The first floor lounge is just so cosy for a romantic evening ....We are going back!

Usually when I come to NYC, I stay in SoHo or the Lower East Side. If you plan to go out in those areas or even up in the East Village or Chelsea, this hotel is a bit out of the way. But the price can't be beat for a Thompson boutique hotel. The subway is close by but Fulton Station is not easy to figure out. You'll also need to transfer to get to where you need to be. Some of the direct lines to that area also don't run on the weekends. The hotel will call a taxi for you so getting out of the area is not an issue...I stayed in a standard room the first night and then upgraded to their biggest suite, both were really great. Really SOFT and heavenly beds. Service was friendly but sometimes slow as they didn't have enough people working the front desk. I'm still working through a dispute with the hotel as their housekeeping through out one of my shopping bags. Usually for the amount of money spent here, I wouldn't have to go through this much trouble for a reimbursement. However, management has been courteous throughout this situation.There is only breakfast room service but many restaurants in the area also deliver. Since you will be in the financial district, many of the neighborhood bars and restaurants might be closed. I'd really only recommend this location if you know the city well and will not be around the hotel much.

I stayed at the Gild Hall in September 2009, while in NYC for a quick break before heading elsewhere int he US on business.The hotel's great - large rooms, clean, and good value.However, the location could be a down-side, depending what you're visiting NYC for. If you're on business, you're right in the heart of things with easy access to Wall Street etc. For leisure, it's less good. Easy access to Battery Park and the ferries, but beyond that you're facing a subway guide to get anywhere - especially weekends, when a lot of the shops and eateries in the immediate area are closed. Fulton Street subway station is also hideously complicated.Also thought that any hotel charging this much should have free wifi.

My husband and I wanted to spend our 25th anniversary in downtown NYC. I booked the Gild Hall Hotel based on reviews and the location. It was a great choice! It's walking distance to the Seaport, the Hudson River walkway/park, and Battery Park. We wanted to do the Ellis Island Tour and also be able to go on long walks, so this area was perfect. The hotel is a funky little place with a great staff - very friendly and attentive. I lost a shopping bag at the bar one night, and the staff really bent over backwards to help me find it. The even offered to watch the security tape to see if it had been stolen. I've never encountered people so willing to go beyond their job description.The room was a good size - the only strange thing is that the bathroom is walled in with frosted glass blocks, so you can see the person on the toilet. Even after 25 years together, that's just too much information. The bed was very comfortable and there was plenty of closet space. The only bad thing about this location is the lack of places for a good breakfast on the weekend. Since it's a business area, a lot of the surrounding shops are closed on the weekend. The diner that the staff directed us to was horrible. I would definitely stay here again.

Booked this over the phone directly with hotel after several websites (including their own) showed no availability. Location was perfect for us since we have family a block away. Room was above-average size for NY standards, interesting decor, nice atmosphere overall. Only hitch was the smoking room they originally assigned; we had to wait about 1/2 hour to be re-assigned but everything worked out OK. Would definitely recommend this if you're looking downtown.

Stayed here for 3 nights before moving mid-town. Loved the location as it was perfect for exploring this part of NY and felt very safe at all times of the day and night. the hotel was very comfortable but like other reviewers did not like the bathroom door - very inappropriate. Didn't find the hotel staff particularly friendly, in fact we felt as though we were just about tolerated. They just answered our questions as briefly as possible and never offered any advice or additional information. On the plus side we never heard any noise from outside our room and the bed was extremely comfortable with excellent bedding. There was no iron in the room but we asked for one and it arrived straight away. All in all a good choice of hotel but didn't want to spend time in the lobby as we felt this was quite depressing with no atmosphere.

Staff were friendly, and the room was comfortable and nicely furnished (but would suggest to them to get rid of the shabby tartan throw rug on the bed - awful). Good location to Southport restaurants and shops, and located just near Wall Street. We had good and inexpensive breakfast at nearby Zeytuna each morning: yogurt, fruit, good coffee or cooked breakfast if you want. Big problem with this hotel is that the room keys need to be re-set constantly (same happened for our friends who also had a room there). Given we were there for four nights, this was a little tiresome. Hotel bar and reception area has nice atmosphere.

Stayed here in June 09, worst weather ever for new york but this hotel was fantastic. Bit difficult to find but once found fantastic.Subways literally around the corner, as is Wall Street, having been going to new york every year for 10 years and this is the first time that I have made it to this area. I found it amazing, there is even a Tiffany store, Trump Hotel but not the same as looking at them in 5th Ave.Going go get the only real negative out of the way..BATHROOM - OMG.. Four girls in the one bedroom, four crazy irish shoppers into the mix and a bathroom that you can see right into..Feel sorry for the person who is on the right hand side of the bed, your nose is literally squeezed into the glass, and boy, there is nothing left to the imagination here.Immediate call down to house keeping to tried to do something with a double bed sheet and thumb tacks which kept falling each time some one entered the bathroom but we had to put up with it.. Why on earth cant they just put something on to the glass like a perspex decal or something.. It really is unacceptable.Front desk where always very friendly, the bell hops at the front door where in a league of their own. On the last day they could not have been better. One of the guys went round the block until he got us a taxi van rather than pay for 2 cabs to take us all plus numerous bags to airport.Weekends, this place really does go to sleep, but come monday morning it is bouncing. On arrival we all received complimentary vouchers for drinks which we forgot about. Didnt eat here, but used one of the carts just across street which was gorgeous..Room service was fantastic, loads and loads of snow white crisp clean towels, shower really powerful and any amount of hot water. Mini bar in room which we emptied to store our own drinks which was a pity.The bedroom was big enough for four, would love to stay again at xmas but the prices are crazy, so if anyone has any good low cost hotels they can recommend please do so.

Everytime we go to New York, we like to stay in a different neighborhood. This time, we picked Financial District, so Gild Hall (of the Thompson Hotel group) was the best choice for us. We were quite happy with the place, despite being a tiny bit worried about the mixed reviews. The decor is a unique mix of old-boy British club meets Zen simplicity. There were lots of quirky touches, such as a rhino footrest in the lobby, and antler chandeliers. Loads of cushy leather sofas to chill. If the names Wes Anderson and Vivian Westwood mean anything to you, you will appreciate the look and feel of this place. The room: A plaid throw on the bed (which has a huge leather headboard) contrasts nicely with clean undecorated walls. The dark blue industrial grade carpet in the room, however, was jarring against the sumptuous and simple details of the room. Having stayed in a number of NYC hotels, I have to say the room size was pretty generous. Toiletries were spare, but nice, from C.O. Bigelows. No shower cap, or other little extras, just lotion, shampoo, conditioner, bar soap. Oh, and no wi-fi, and they charge 10 clams for internet. Wah?The front desk and service were lovely, the bar was fun, and attracted what seemed like locals and regulars, mixing with out-of-towners. The restaurant Libertine was closed for summer, so I cannot comment on that. But there are tons of bars and restaurants nearby in every direction. Don't be misled by those who say there's nothing down in the Financial District. We found good pizza, old-skool diners, and more. The streets are labyrinthine, so it's not as easy to naviagate as the gridded parts of NYC. Subways are nearby. Overall, this hip cozy lodge was a pleasant surprise.

OK, I did have concerns about staying at this hotel, since, I am a female, traveling alone on business. My company wanted me to stay at an affordable hotel within walking distance to the financial district. So, at $199/night this was it. I had a hard time finding it, since it is on a side street, but I was able to find it. It is Art Deco decor and a small, boutique hotel, so there will not be a lavish lobby; but there is someone at the front desk. The staff was very, very nice and made me feel comfortable. I was able to walk to South Street Seaport by myself and no problems at all. I was able to shop, drink and eat. Fun. One of the days, I went to a spa to get a massage in the neighborhood one of the days. And, most of all I found some really great places to eat/shop...Century 21 (the best store on the planet) - within walking distance (about 3 blocks), Crumbs bakery, near wall street - Double YUM and Adrienne's Pizza Bar on Stone Street for the best pizza. It is completely safe. Back to the hotel, the room is very small, the halls are small too. The bathroom doors are dusted class. I wouldn't recommend a family or a couple, at least not the room I was in. Oh, they do have condoms in the room too. Just in case, if you meet someone along the way...;-) They also have a library on the 2nd floor/lounge too. I had a great time. Oh, one more thing, I am also a travel agent and I would recommend this hotel for single travelers or business. Fun and safe and bit of real New York City!

Definitely not a 4 star rating. Pricey hotel for what it offers. No restaurant or food (room service) available in hotel. Why not at least have snacks in the bar? Rooms are clean but really small. I hurt my shin on bed frame. Not enough drawer space for clothes. Closet was ok. No coffee maker or iron in room. Bathroom glass door needs to go (what was the reasoning behind this semi-see through door??). To make matters worse our bathroom door had a defective lock and couldn’t stay shut! We couldn’t believe that they charge $10 per day for the internet! Is this a New York thing? Cheaper hotels have free internet!Staff was great (Friendly and helpful).Hallway decor is nice and unique. We found the lobby somewhat dull. One night there was a wedding party. We tried to get a drink at the bar on the first floor but the wedding guests were hoarding all the space around the bar and some of then seemed reluctant on creating a pathway for us to order our drinks. The bartender seemed unconcerned about us.If you are ever in Chicago, try Hotel Blake. In Washington DC try Hotel Lombardy, you'll see why Gild Hall does not deserve a 4 star rating. These other hotels are rated 3.5 star but are surely 4.5 star based on the Gild Hall rating. They are also less pricey than Gild Hall. But then, its New York!… the streets around the hotel were full of garbage bags. Wall Street?? More like garbage street. Everything seemd just crammed in….. well!

I stayed here in a room with too big and comfortable doublebeds with three friends for 50$/night/person.The only negative thing about the whole stay for our kind of trip is the fact that room and baathroom are only divided only by a thin pane of frosted glass. That carried no weight since all the rest was positive:1. The location is unbeatable in my eyes. Starbucks, Supermarket (with all the freshly prepared foods you can imagine), pharmacies and several bars and diners around the corner. The latter ones have food and drinkss at reasonable prices and appear NOT to be typically tourist-places but places for the people working there. We enjoyed those place much more than places in midtown where we stayed later. The liveliness on the streets from early in the morning till the late afternoon also seems to be much more that of the "real New York" than the life in many other places we have seen. Also are both the 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 J, A, C, E, M, Q, R, W and Z - trains in 5 minute walking distance and take you to basically the whole city including Midtown, upper/lower West-/Eastside, the nice parts of Brooklyn (you might want to change to a northbound G...), the Bronx and Queens.It's a short walk to Ground Zero, Century21, the port and lots of other places of interest.2. Both the room, bathroom, lobby, bar and the rest of the hotel were clean at any given time. The staff was friendly, professional and unobtrusive.3. The room was not huge, but there was enough place for all our stuff on the floor, in the dresser and the closet. It included a bigscreen tv, an ipod-dockingstation, a safe, a minibar, an icemachine on the fourth (and 14th?) floor, a silent and powerfull ac and a nice bathtub. The interior is classy with leather and dark woods as seen on the pictures provided by tripadvisor. Also the rest of the Hotel has an elegant appearence.__All in all our stay at Gild Hall was near perfect and not only better than our stays at "Swiss 1291", "the Edison Hotel" and "the Portland Square Hotel" but also better than the stay at the 39th floor in the "Waldorf towers" where the TV didn't work and where we had to open the main door by ourselves, unlike at Gild Hall.

Stayed here for four nights in July.From the moment I checked in staff were extremely friendly and very happy to answer any questions I had regarding travel and anything else to do with the hotel.The hotel has a lovely decor which has a "trendy" feel to it. The restaurant looked a little pricey and was pitched as "english gastro", being and Englishman myself I steered away from it but from what I could see the food looked pretty good.To be honest, in this location you have thousands of choice of places to eat, so eating in the hotel would be a silly idea anyway, go explore!The business centre was pretty useful, containing a few shared PC's and a networked HP printer (which I used to print directly to from my laptop).The rooms are fully equiped with LCD TV, minibar, bathrobes, wardrobe, and small desk.Other people have mentioned the rooms are a little small, I would agree if we were comparing against other outer city US hotels, but the rooms were pretty much the standard size you get in any European hotels and inner city hotels. A/C in the rooms was great and even with the lovely duck down covers (in summer!) I slept like a baby.The hotel is very close to Fulton street subway which is *fantastic* as it's on stacks of subway lines, you can get anywhere in manhatten very very quickly. It's quite easy to get lost in the maze of streets around the hotel, but this is downtown in the financial district, what do you expect? with a good map you can find it perfectly.The bathroom was great, very clean and bright and a powerful over-bath shower and fully stocked with the usual hotel condiments. Other reviewers have complained about the transparent material used between the bathroom and the room, it is in fact shaded so you can't see through it at all apart from the odd shadow and wouldn't be a problem for people sharing a twin room.My only complaints were:- $10/day for wireless, at a top end hotel pitched towards business this was totally unacceptable, even smaller low-end hotels have free wifi these days.- Wardrobe space was OK, but no drawer space at all, for longer stays a few drawers to store clothes would have been required, with two people in the room we struggled.Otherwise I would highly recommend this hotel for business (since it's a few blocks from wall street) use or for tourists since it's perfectly connected, a short walk from the downtown sites and a 10 minute subway ride from the rest of the city.

Like the other review here, I too stayed at the Gild Hall on the night/morning of the atrocious fire alarm. The difference is that I was approached at reception and an immediate, remarkably sincere, apology was extended. Although I was in a hurry to catch a flight the front desk did all they could to mend the wounds of being awoken at such a ridiculous hour (I am from the west coast and had logged a mere 3 hours of sleep!). Throughout my stay I found the front desk to be warm, friendly, funny & helpful (especially Kelli). At this price point I would call the Gild Hall a good value.

The room and bathroom were of a reasonable size, nicely furnished and clean. Wireless internet is an extra 10 USD per day. A few unusual extras were available in the room (condoms etc).The hotel is located in downtown Manhattan which may not be suitable for all though there is a metro station located closeby.The only issue I had was that the fire alarm went off at 0500 on the first night we stayed (followed by an announcement that this was a false alarm). The alarm then repeatedly sounded until the morning though was stopped quickly on each occasion. This meant that it was not possible to get any sleep from 0500. I realise that this is not necessarily the hotel's fault but it would have been nice for the hotel to apologise when we went through reception in the morning, which would have been good customer service.

Stayed here over the July 4th 2009, very cool hotel, nice common areas, very friendly staff, great access to much of tribecca and the seaport. Its nice to be able to remove your self a bit from the midtown crowds, on a weekend such as the fourth, and still be so close to so much.
Location, price, staff, room, etc.... perfect. You cannot go wrong with this hotel. It is a gem.

I rarely stay downtown -- generally in midtown instead. Gild Hall has very nice common areas that are warm and old school feeling in a trendy way. good experience. If I needed to stay downtown again, I would definitely consider again.

My boyfriend and I were visiting NYC just for the night to see some friends and decided to get a hotel instead of crashing on someone's couch. Someone recommended Gild Hall and we booked it. The whole stay was great. The front desk staff was friendly and efficient when we checked in (and gave us 2 free drink tickets for the Libertine Bar in the hotel). When we went to the bar before dinner, we had great service again. We ordered the crab cake and when a mix-up in the kitchen caused it to come out somewhat late, we got another free round of drinks unsolicited (we weren't in any rush). The decor was very cool - "modern hunting lodge chic", if I had to define it. The room was comfortable, spacious and clean. The automatic light on the mini-bar was a sleek feature (although, some wires must have been crossed in our room because it turned on and off on its own all night.) My only complaint with the room was the very strange design feature of a frosted glass bathroom. You could see right in from the outside! The hotel isn't in a *great* area of the city as far as Things To Do goes, but it was very quiet and cabs are easy to find. I would definitely recommend a stay at Gild Hall.

The staff is excellent - very helpful. courteous and go out of their way to ensure that their guests have what they need. The room was a pleasant surprise in size, accommodating 4 wormen with plenty of suitcases,makeup bags and snacks. The only drawback is as mentioned in previous posts, the glass wall for the bathroom is not everyone's cup of tea. If they would block out the middle section it would help but when the bathroom light was turned on in the early morning it was tough for those who wished to sleep in. We are adaptable so it didn't bug us too much because the rest of the room made up for it. The restaurant for dinner was delicious and the staff there were great.The location is perfect for catching the subway, getting coffee at Starbucks, food nearby at the Deli and walking to South Seaport for a meal. We will be coming back to this hotel when we make a return trip to NY. I was apprehensive about the trip and check trip advisor before I ever book a hotel, so I thought it only fair to give my feedback and say I was not disappointed in my choice.

We stayed at the Gild Hall on May 29th for our 15th anniversary. I got the night as part of a package with dinner through Skyauciton.com. While we live in Brooklyn, we rarely spend time in that part of Manhattan so it was a nice experience. We felt like tourists for a night. The rooms were nice and chic, reminded me of the W Hotels. Beds were comfortable and the location is ok, but more geared for weekdays as evenings and weekends are pretty dead in the financial district. Having said that, there seem to be some pretty good rates (by New York standards) for the hotel on weekends and you can walk to South Street Seaport, Liberty Park, etc. By the way, there is a great little specialty grocery store/restaurant called Zaytunas very close to the hotel. During lunch time, the basement of the store is a cafeteria type deli with lots of great Medditeranean/Middle Eastern kabobs, salads, pizzas, etc.

We were excited to stay in a boutique hotel by the Thomson Hotel company, and severely disappointed by this overpriced hotel that is not properly maintained. I am a frequent traveller & stay at Marriott whenever possible. Most important to me is a convenient hotel with clean rooms that are functional. My 1st complaint with this hotel is the bar in the lobby that is not cleaned properly. If you arrive at 1pm, 5pm, 10pm or 5am, it smelled of beer and cocktails (as though they were spilled on the floor).But the real "treat" is in the rooms. The room was incredibly small (maybe a little over 200 sq ft), and yet it featured a king bed. There was very little room to store luggage and get around the room. Then there was this misguided notion of a glass wall for the bathroom facing the room (actually, it was pretty much in the room) ... you could exactly see the person in the bathroom & the toilet was right next to the glass wall (that was pleasant!). Also, the rooms and halls were in need of refurbishment.Given the location and price, we expected far more. We stayed at the Sofitel for the last few days of our trip in New York, and had no complaints ... Gild Hall is very, very mediocre and not worth the money.
user_name:
DQC_76
New York City, New York

review_body: Good business hotel - great location in Manhattan, quiet yet at the centre of things.Rooms are small-ish, but not at all uncomfortable. Room has fairly good facilities - mini-bar, internet (to pay for), toiletries etc.Would be good if they can shove in a 'reading chair' or sofa ... a single seater. Also a coffee maker is sorely missed!!!Otherwise a very pleasant place. Staff are polite and professional. Hotel has mini-gym on each floor, for the so inclined.

We only stayed at GildHall for two nights whilst passing through Manhattan but really felt involved and appreciated. The manager and concierge went out of their way to make us feel comfortable and to ensure we had a brilliant time in New York. The room was large and very well appointed and with Kiehls products. It is a little out of the way but we like that, its only a short taxi drive from midtown and Soho and as it is so close to Brookyn bridge its great for an evening stroll. All in all this is the best hotel I've stayed in for a long time!

What a superb hotel !! Comfort was excellent, rooms super clean and cosy.Everything was perfect. Staff is really nice and helpfull.Large and comfortable bed.Cookies, ice at arrival, newspaper offered every morning.SUPER QUITE.Breakfast was just ok and we've been charged the Espresso we asked for everyday.Infos :- iPod & iPhone dock in all rooms (charge and listen music)- a great METRO stations at 1 min walk : Fulton st- 5 min walk from Ground Zero / Century 21 (perfect for low price shopping)- Safety box- 5 min walk from the brooklyn bridge!!!WARNING : be aware that Lower Manatthan is a BUSINESS DISTRICT. It means it's crawded on weekdays and dead on weekends. Nothing particular to do at night.If it's your first time in NYC, consider booking an hotel in Midtown East or West.

We were looking for a 4-star hotel to join our friends in the Financial District of Manhattan so we went on Priceline and got this little gem for a great price (130$/night). We had looked it up on the internet and were delighted to see a hotel with a distinct designer vibe. It's as if the Scottish designer duo Collin and Justin went crazy and decorated the entire hotel!Upon our arrival, the staff was courteous and suggested an excellent Italian restaurant nearby (Giardino D'Oro). Although on the smaller side, our room (#83) was beautiful with a large comfortable bed with exquisite Egyptian cotton sheets (Frette). The large LCD tv made my boyfriend very happy. It's a smaller but very cozy and extremely beautiful hotel. I would suggest going there if you like boutique hotels.

Gild Hall was the first Priceline hotel we ever stayed at, so we were delighted to have gotten this upscale, funky hotel for only $125 a night. The decor is a very distinctive hybrid of chic and rustic -- to this day we call it the Hipster Hunting Lodge. We'll be happy if our Priceline bid lands us there again.The staff was very courteous, and housekeeping was thorough. There were nice little perks, like the tasty Fat Witch brownies waiting for us, and the overhead lighting fixture that appeared to be made out of a cast iron wagon wheel. The bed was huge and comfortable. Staying in the Financial District is more interesting than you'd think. There was a branch of The Strand Bookstore right around the corner, and plenty of places to eat. By day it's bustling, but at night it's so quiet that you'd think you were in the suburbs. It's perfect for travelers who aren't into night clubbing and partying.The room was lovely, but beware the rooms with glass bathroom doors! I loathe this trend in interior decorating, which seems to be trying to imply that sharing all at potty time is somehow sexy. The glass was frosted, but the toilet is right up next to it and you can see everything. My partner and I adore each other, but we don't go to this level of personal exposure. I don't know if they have some rooms with normal bathroom doors, but you should ask if this is a problem for you (I wish we had).Other than that, we enjoyed the hotel very much and everything worked as it should.
